subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 100-0 Introduction to Biological Sciences at Northwestern (1 Unit)
description: For participants in Bio&ChemEXCEL summer program. An overview of recent advances in biological research and leadership within the field of biology. Taken with CHEM 100-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 101-7 College Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and introducing skills necessary to thriving at Northwestern. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 101-8 First-Year Writing Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and focused on the fundamentals of effective, college-level written communication. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 103-0 Diversity of Life (1 Unit)
description: Comparative survey of organisms, emphasizing adaptation and phylogenetic relationships. Particular emphasis on animals. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 104-0 Plant-People Interactions (1 Unit)
description: Biology and history of the interaction of humans and flowering plants. Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 109-0 The Nature of Plants (1 Unit)
description: Plant adaptations for growth, survival, and reproduction. Plant defense against herbivory, pollination, and seed dispersal. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 115-6 College Seminar (1 Unit)
description: For participants in the NUBioscientist program. Biological Thought & Action; preparatory to BIOL_SCI 116-6 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 116-6 First-Year Writing Seminar (1 Unit)
description: For participants in the NUBioscientist program. Science Research Preparation; follows BIOL_SCI 115-6 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 150-0 Human Genetics (1 Unit)
description: Basic principles of human inheritance and genetic variation. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 164-0 Basic Genetics and Evolution (1 Unit)
description: Principles of inheritance as they apply to evolution. May not receive credit after taking BIOL_SCI 203-0 . Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 201-0 Molecular Biology (1 Unit)
description: This course focuses on how information is stored and propagated in DNA, and used and regulated to generate proteins at the proper time and location. It also applies this information to understanding fundamentals of biotechnology. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 201-MG Mentored Study Program (0 Unit)
description: Study sessions facilitated by undergraduate peer leaders, for students enrolled in BIOL_SCI 201-0 . Meets weekly in small groups to collaboratively review material, solve practice problems, clarify concepts, and enhance study strategies. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 201-SG Peer-Guided SG: Molecular Biology (0 Unit)
description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 201-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 202-0 Cell Biology (1 Unit)
description: This course covers how biomolecules function together to generate the complexity of cells, and how cells behave collectively to communicate with each other and to enact key decisions, such as proliferation and cell death. BIOL_SCI 201-0 to register for this course. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 232-0 . Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 202-SG Peer-Guided SG: Cell Biology (0 Unit)
description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 202-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 203-0 Genetics and Evolution (1 Unit)
description: This course provides an analytic framework for studying the flow of biological information across generations, and understanding how phenotypes reveal biological mechanisms. This framework is applied to development, cancer, the history of life, and mechanisms governing the evolution and distribution of organisms over time. BIOL_SCI 202-0 to register for this course. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 233-0 . Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 203-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: Genetics and Evolution (0 Unit)
description: Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U. Co-requisite: BIOL_SCI 203-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 213-0 Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (0 Unit)

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 232-0 Molecular and Cellular Processes Laboratory (0.34 Unit)
description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of cell and molecular biology. Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 202-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 233-0 Genetics and Molecular Processes Laboratory (0.34 Unit)
description: Laboratory techniques and experiments in fundamental aspects of transmission genetics and molecular biology. BIOL_SCI 232-0 . Must be taken concurrently with BIOL_SCI 203-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 234-0 Investigative Laboratory (0.34 Unit)
description: A culminating life-science laboratory experience. BIOL_SCI 233-0 .

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 240-0 Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology for ISP - 1 (1 Unit)
description: This course aims to provide a framework for understanding the chemistry, structure and function of life’s smallest functional units known as cells. Starting out with a basic description of inherent properties of biological macromolecules, the course deals with information storage, the flow of genetic information, cytoskeleton, cell organelles, and cell division.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 241-0 Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology for ISP - 2 (1 Unit)
description: The course takes an in depth look at how the chemical and physical properties of organic molecules drive all aspects of life. Focus on principles of chemical evolution/diversification, biological membranes, membrane transport processes, enzyme structure and function, molecular signaling and design principles of the metabolic engine that enables the breakdown and synthesis of biological macromolecules. CHEM 171-0 , CHEM 172-0 , CHEM 212-1, BIOL_SCI 240-0 , and ISP standing.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 301-0 Principles of Biochemistry (1 Unit)
description: Biochemical processes. BIOL_SCI 201-0 and CHEM 210-1 or CHEM 212-1 or CHEM 215-1 or CHEM 217-1 to register for this course. Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 301-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: Principles of Biochemistry (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in BIOL_SCI 301-0 .  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 302-0 Fundamentals of Neurobiology (1 Unit)

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 303-0 Molecular Neurobiology (1 Unit)

subject: BIOL_SCI

description: An exploration of the functions of the human body at the tissue, organ, and organ system level. Emphasis on homeostatic mechanisms and interdependence within organs and organ systems and the influence of modulatory systems. Topics will include, but are not limited to: nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. BIOL_SCI 201-0 , BIOL_SCI 202-0 , and CHEM 132-0 , CHEM 152-0 , or CHEM 172-0 . Natural Sciences Distro Area

title_units: BIOL_SCI 315-0 Advanced Cell Biology (1 Unit)

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 319-0 Biology of Animal Viruses (1 Unit)
description: Virus structure, synthesis of viral nucleic acids and proteins, the interaction of the viral and cellular genomes. BIOL_SCI 202-0 , BIOL_SCI 203-0 , and BIOL_SCI 301-0 to register for this course.

subject: BIOL_SCI
title_units: BIOL_SCI 323-0 Bioinformatics:  Sequence and Structure Analysis (1 Unit)

subject: BIOL_SCI

title_units: BIOL_SCI 339-0 Critical Topics in Ecology and Conservation (1 Unit)

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 101-7 College Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and introducing skills necessary to thrive at Northwestern. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and focused on the fundamentals of effective, college-level written communication. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 210-0 Introduction to African American Literature (1 Unit)
description: Literature of Black people in the United States from slavery to freedom. Works of major writers and significant but unsung bards of the past. subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 211-0 Literatures of the Black World (1 Unit)
description: Introductory survey of fiction, poetry, drama, folktales, and other literary forms of Africa and the African diaspora. Texts may span the precolonial, colonial, and postcolonial periods and cover central themes, such as memory, trauma, spirituality, struggle, identity, freedom, and humor. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: BLK_ST

BLK_ST 212-2 and HISTORY 212-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses. description: Introductory survey of the history of Africans and their descendants across the globe. African civilizations prior to European colonialism, encounters between Africa and Europe, movements of "Africans" to the Americas and elsewhere, and development of Black Introductory survey of the history of Africans and their descendants across the globe. African civilizations prior to European colonialism, encounters between Africa and Europe, movements of "Africans" to the Americas and elsewhere, and development of Bblack communities in and outside Africa. subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 220-0 Civil Rights and Black Liberation (1 Unit)
description: The Northern and Southern Civil Rights Movements and the rise of Black nationalism and feminism, 1945-72. Ethics  Values Distro Area Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 225-0 African-American Culture (1 Unit)
description: Survey of African American culture from slavery to the present. Relation of African American culture to African and Euro-American cultures, the Black Atlantic as a unit of analysis, representations of Blackness in the public imagination. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 236-0 Introduction to Black Studies (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to the discipline of Black Studies using key historical and theoretical texts. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 245-0 The Black Diaspora and Transnationality (1 Unit)
description: Examination of events, movements, theories, and texts that have shaped development of the African diaspora. Topics include slavery, abolitionism, pan-Africanism, the culture-politics nexus, hip-hop, AIDS, and linkages among gender, sexuality, and diasporic sensibilities. Historical Studies Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 247-0 Black Life. Trans Life. (1 Unit)
description: This course will introduce students to the parameters and textures of Black life, Trans life, and Black Trans life. Popular discourse has either depicted Black Trans people as glamorous superstars or always and already predisposed to death. This course, then, seeks to usefully complicate these narratives and focus on Black and Trans *life*. U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 250-0 Race, Class and Gender (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to scholarship and key theories that treat race, class, and gender as intersecting social constructs. Race, class, and gender in work, family and reproduction, education, poverty, sexuality, and consumer culture. How race, class, and gender inform identity, ideology, and politics to incite social change. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 251-0 Introduction to Critical Mixed Race Studies (1 Unit)
description: Exploration of demographic trends in interracial and interethnic marriages to highlight the complexity of the American experience. Special attention to mixed-race experiences portrayed in film and novels. BLK_ST 251-0 and ASIAN_AM 251-0 are taught together; students may not receive credit for both courses. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 259-0 Introduction to African-American Drama (1 Unit)
description: Thematic and historical survey of African American drama. Sociopolitical context, the aesthetic reflected in the work, impact on African American and general theater audiences. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST

description: Advanced introduction to critical theories of race, gender, and sexuality in the African diaspora from the 19th century to today. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST

description: Introduces students to the variety of Black religions that developed during and after the Atlantic slave trade up to the present. Explores these traditions as continuities/changes of West African religious cosmologies. Examines the interplay between religion, politics, and the constructions of racial identities within various forms of Christianity, Islam, and other expressive cultures. RELIGION 262-0 and BLK_ST 262-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both. Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 275-0 Africans and African Americans: Cultural Entanglements (1 Unit)
description: Students will explore how the afterlives of colonialism and slavery have shaped the contemporary relationships between Africans and African Americans. Students will explore how writers, musicians, performers, and scholars excavate the ongoing intimacies between the continent and the African diaspora, in a post-Civil Rights U.S. and in contemporary Africa. Global Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 310-0 Contemporary Asian Black Relations (1 Unit)
description: Divides between these groups, as well as areas of positive cross-cultural collaboration. Historical analysis of reparations, the 1992 Los Angeles riots, and affirmative action. Cross-racial exchange in youth expressions, popular culture, hip-hop. BLK_ST 310-0 and ASIAN_AM 310-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses. Ethics  Values Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 315-0 Religion in the Black Atlantic (1 Unit)
description: Afro-Atlantic religions since the 1400s; traditions of Orisa devotion and monotheisms; religion and revolution in African slave religion; racialization and empire; theories of religion, materialities, and diaspora. subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 317-0 Black Political Thought (1 Unit)
description: Black protest, Black radical politics and Black-led demonstrations are nothing new. How should we understand the motivations and ideas involved in Black radical politics? This course seeks to introduce students to the historical and political underpinnings of issues and questions raised by what Cedric Robinson famously referred to as the "Black Radical Tradition." Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 320-0 Social Meaning of Race (1 Unit)
description: Race as a social concept and recurrent cause of differentiation in multiracial societies. Impact of race on social, cultural, economic, and political institutions. Discussion of prejudice, racism, and discrimination. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 325-0 Education for Black Liberation (1 Unit)
description: This class considers what it means to conceptualize, articulate, and actualize a liberatory Black educational project within U.S. public schools structured by anti-Blackness. The course treats historical and contemporary manifestations of anti-Blackness in schools, as well as the ways Black students, educators, administrators, community and family members, and scholars have worked towards liberation. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 327-0 Politics of Black Popular Culture (1 Unit)
description: Examination of the debates within Black communities about the proper role and function of Black art and artists in relation to Black politics. Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: BLK_ST

description: Experiences and leadership of African American women in major events in recent history, including anti-lynching, women's suffrage, civil rights movements, and World War II. Historical Studies Distro Area Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

description: Readings in classic Black American fiction. The author as creator and participant. Works of Wright, Ellison, Baldwin, and others. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 334-0 Gender and Black Masculinity (1 Unit)
description: Perceptions and constructions of Black masculinity within African American and "American" cultures in the United States; readings in gender and sexuality studies, feminist theory, African American studies, and cultural studies. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 335-0 Race and Literature in 19th Century America (1 Unit)
description: Examination of the evolution and persistence of the notion of "race" in 19th century America, with attention to the origins of the idea of race in the West. Focus on the multiracial character of 19th century America.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 339-0 Unsettling Whiteness (1 Unit)
description: Making the historical, political, and cultural formation of whiteness in Western modernity visible and narratable for commentary and analysis. Particular reference to contemporary culture. Historical Studies Distro Area Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 342-0 Comparative Slavery (1 Unit)
description: Traces slavery across historical epochs and geographic contexts, with an emphasis on Latin America, the Caribbean, and the United States. Ethics  Values Distro Area Historical Studies Distro Area Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 345-0 Afro-Latin America (1 Unit)
description: Exploration of Afro-Latin communities, cultures, and identities throughout Latin America and the Hispanic diaspora after 1800. Emergence of race and nation in modern Latin America, migration, gender, Afro-Latin spiritual systems and religion, family, and politics. Historical Studies Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 350-0 Theorizing Blackness (1 Unit)
description: Advanced introduction to critical theories of race and racialization. Investigation of Blackness as a category of critical analysis for analyzing Afro-diasporic formations. Consideration of how Blackness is shaped by gender, class, sexuality, and nationality. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 355-0 Diaspora Studies (1 Unit)
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the significance of diasporas, their histories, and common dynamics, illustrated with examples drawn from a wide range of cases. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 360-0 Major Authors (1 Unit)
description: In-depth examination of a selected author's body of work. Choice of author varies. May be repeated for credit with change of author. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 363-0 Racism in Western Modernity (1 Unit)
description: Impact of racism in the formation of Western modernity. Critical conceptual and historical analyses of the social formation of "race" and the historical implications of racism in the contemporary West.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 365-0 Black Chicago (1 Unit)
description: Surveys the social, cultural, and political history of African Americans in Chicago, including the Great Migration, the Black political machine, Black Chicago music, racial segregation, internal class stratification, and the role of Black churches. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl U.S. Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 375-0 Post Colonial African American Studies (1 Unit)
description: Development of critical approaches to African American studies from the perspectives of postcolonial analysis. In particular, examination of the meaning of the colonial in the formation of African American experiences and the significance of modernity, race, and Black politics in the historical contexts of the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 378-0 Harlem Renaissance (1 Unit)
description: African American political and social movements and cultural production in theater, music, visual arts, and literature from 1915 to 1930. BLK_ST 210-0 or another African American literature course. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 379-0 Black Women Writers (1 Unit)
description: Intensive, multi-genre examination of the contribution of Black women to African American, women's, and American literature, with consideration of the factors and figures that have influenced the reception of Black women's writings across time. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 380-0 Topics in African-American Studies (1 Unit)
description: Advanced work on social, cultural, or historical topics. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 381-0 Topics in Transnational Black Studies (1 Unit)
description: Examination of texts such as novels, poetry, film, drama, slave narratives, political manifestos, and historical texts in order to compare how people from across the African diaspora have approached issues of identity, culture, and community.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 390-0 Research Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Methods of researching the Black experience. Identification of research problems; location, selection, and critique of relevant literature; data gathering and analysis; report writing. Topics vary.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 396-0 Internship in Black Studies (1 Unit)
description: Analysis of social and cultural institutions through field study and participant observation. Entails a final submission overseen by a Northwestern faculty member.

subject: BLK_ST
title_units: BLK_ST 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: Open to advanced students with consent of instructor. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 101-0 Introduction to Biomedical Engineering (0 Unit)
description: Information to 1) help students determine if BME is the right major for them and 2) learn how to make the most of their undergraduate experience. The field of biomedical engineering, career and research opportunities, ethics.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 207-0 BME Lab: Experimental Design (0.5 Unit)
description: A laboratory course focusing on quantitative physiological measurements and analyses, instrument characterization, statistical design of experiments, and training in preparation and organization of laboratory notes and reports. BMD_ENG 220-0 or IEMS 303-0 or MECH_ENG 359-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 220-0 Introduction to Biomedical Statistics (1 Unit)
description: Basic statistical concepts presented with emphasis on their relevance to biological and medical investigations.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 250-0 Thermodynamics (1 Unit)
description: Physical and chemical principles as applied to biological systems and medical devices. Topics include material balances, thermodynamics, solution chemistry, electrochemistry, surface chemistry, transport, and kinetics. MATH 228-1 ; CHEM 132-0 , CHEM 152-0 , or CHEM 172-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 270-0 Fluid Mechanics (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of fluid mechanics and their applications to biological systems. BMD_ENG 271-0 , GEN_ENG 205-4 and MATH 228-2 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 271-0 Introduction to Biomechanics (1 Unit)
description: Analysis of stresses and deformations in solids. Problems in biomechanics, with emphasis on assumptions appropriate to modeling biological materials including bone, skin, muscle, and cell membranes. GEN_ENG 205-2 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 304-0 Quantitative Systems Physiology (1 Unit)
description: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune systems, including physiology and pathophysiology. Case studies and a design team project. Integrated lab activities; no separate section. PHYSICS 135-2 ; junior standing recommended.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 305-0 Quantitative Systems Physiology (1 Unit)
description: Cellular mechanisms of and quantitative systems' approach to human renal, digestive, endocrine, and metabolic physiology. Integrated lab activities; no separate section.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 306-0 Quantitative Systems Physiology (1 Unit)
description: Functional/structural aspects of  vertebrate nervous system. Neural biophysics.  Integrated lab activities; no separate section. PHYSICS 135-2 ; junior standing recommended.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 308-0 Biomedical Signals and Circuits (1.25 Units)
description: Time and frequency domain analysis: convolution representation, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, frequency response, filtering, sampling. PHYSICS 135-2 or consent of instructor; BMD_ENG 207-0 (can be taken concurrently).

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 309-0 Biomedical Systems Analysis (1.25 Units)
description: Introduction to linear systems analysis. Time and frequency domain techniques for analyzing linear systems, emphasizing their applications to biomedical systems. Python-based problem sets and a summative instrumentation and analysis lab project illustrate topics covered in class. BMD_ENG 207-0 ; BMD_ENG 308-0 ; BMD_ENG 220-0 ; GEN_ENG 205-4 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 311-0 Computational Genomics (1 Unit)
description: The course introduces state-of-the-art genomic sequencing technologies and computational modeling of high-throughput sequencing datasets. Through the course, students will learn how to apply these experimental and computational genomics technologies to study gene expression regulation underlying various biological processes, such as oncogenesis. Students will also apply computational and statistical skills, using linux and R/Matlab/Python. BMD_ENG 220-0 ; BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 312-0 Biomedical Applications in Machine Learning (1 Unit)
description: Supervised learning tasks such as regression and classification, Convolutional Neural Networks and image analysis techniques and hidden Markov models, unsupervised learning approaches such as clustering and dimensionality reduction will be applied to both structured (numerical) and image data. All models will be implemented in Python, either from scratch or using high-level libraries. BMD_ENG 220-0 , GEN_ENG 205-1 , MATH 220-1 , MATH 220-2 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 313-0 Wearable Devices: From Sensing to Biomedical Inference (1 Unit)
description: This course will review the challenges and opportunities associated with using wearable devices to infer biomedical information about individuals and populations. It will cover techniques from signal processing, machine learning, and artificial intelligence relevant to this objective. Content will be taught using a series of projects relevant to the quantification of human movement and rehabilitation medicine. BMD_ENG 207-0 and BMD_ENG 220-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 317-0 Biochemical Sensors (1 Unit)
description: Theory, design, and applications of biochemical sensors used in medical diagnosis, biomedical research, and patient monitoring. Detection of biomolecules with optical, electrochemical, mass spectrometry and other sensors. Start-up translation of sensor technology. BIOL_SCI 201-0 ; CHEM 215-1 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 323-0 Visual Engineering Science (1 Unit)
description: Mammalian visual system. Physiological optics.  Visual image representation and interpretation. Visual adaptation. Motion. Color vision. PHYSICS 135-2 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 325-0 Introduction to Medical Imaging (1 Unit)
description: Diagnostic X-rays; X-ray film and radiographic image; computed tomography; ultrasound. Prerequisites: Undergraduate students must have completed PHYSICS 135-3 and BMD_ENG 309 (or equivalent course covering Fourier transform and other Signals concepts) to enroll in this course. PHYSICS 135-3 and knowledge of Fourier concepts.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 327-0 Magnetic Resonance Imaging (1 Unit)
description: Nuclear magnetic resonance; two-dimensional Fourier transform, spinecho and gradientecho imaging; gradient and RF hardware. PHYSICS 135-3 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 333-0 Modern Optical Microscopy & Imaging (1 Unit)
description: Rigorous introduction to principles, current trends, emerging technologies, and biomedical applications of modern optical microscopy. BMD_ENG 220-0 , GEN_ENG 205-4 , PHYSICS 135-3 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 340-0 Pharmaceutical Engineering: From Discovery to Therapeutics (1 Unit)
description: This course will take students through the process of drug development from initial innovative concept and identified medical need, to proof of efficacy, clinical trials, and translation to ‘big pharma’.  Professor Moskal will draw upon his experience from academia and industry to chart out each critical step of drug development; additional industry experts will present guest lectures. CHEM 215-1 or be BME MS/PhD student to enroll in this class.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 343-0 Biomaterials and Medical Devices (1 Unit)
description: Structure-property relationships for biomaterials. Metal, ceramic, and polymeric implant materials and their implant applications. Interactions of materials with the body. BIOL_SCI 201-0 , BIOL_SCI 202-0 (can be taken concurrently), CHEM 215-1 , MAT_SCI 201-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 344-0 Biological Performance of Materials (1 Unit)
description: Structure-property relationships of materials, physical chemistry of surfaces and interfaces, materials-tissue interactions, applications to the selection and design of materials for medical implants and devices. BIOL_SCI 201-0 , BIOL_SCI 202-0 (can be taken concurrently), CHEM 215-1 , MAT_SCI 201-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 346-0 Tissue Engineering (1 Unit)
description: In vivo molecular, cellular, and organ engineering, with emphasis on the foundations, techniques, experiments, and clinical applications of tissue engineering. BIOL_SCI 201-0 , BIOL_SCI 202-0 (can be taken concurrently), CHEM 215-1 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 347-0 Foundations of Regenerative Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Embryonic development, stem cell engineering, somatic regeneration, genome and transcriptome modifications, cell and tissue-level regenerative engineering. BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 348-0 Applications of Regenerative Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Mechanisms of human disease, development and application of molecular, cellular, and tissue-level regenerative engineering strategies to selected human disorders, including neurodegenerative disorders, stroke, cystic fibrosis, cirrhosis, diabetes, muscular degenerative disorders, and skin injury. BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 353-0 Bioelectronics (1 Unit)
description: Development and design of sensors, stimulators, and their medical devices for biointegrated electronics. Materials design and fabrication of passive and active components for sensitive, multimodal, and robust wearable and implantable devices.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 354-0 Bioelectronics Lab (1 Unit)
description: Laboratories focused on the practical implementation, instrumentation, and fabrication of wearables and skinsensing. Applications range from vital sign monitoring to rehabilitation.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 365-0 Control of Human Limbs and Their  Artificial Replacements (1 Unit)
description: Human movement, biomechanics, skeletal and muscular anatomy, comparative anatomy, muscle physiology, and locomotion. Engineering design of artificial limbs.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 366-0 Biomechanics of Movement (1 Unit)
description: Engineering mechanics applied to analyze human movement, including models of muscle and tendon, kinematics of joints, and dynamics of multi-joint movement. Applications in sports, rehabilitation, and orthopedics. BMD_ENG 271-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 371-0 Mechanics of Biological Tissue (1 Unit)
description: Stress and strain for small and large deformations. Nonlinear elastic, viscoelastic, pseudo-elastic, and biphasic models. BMD_ENG 271-0 ; GEN_ENG 205-3 ; GEN_ENG 205-4 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 377-0 Intermediate Fluid Mechanics (1 Unit)
description: Fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics. Kinematics, mass and momentum balances, constitutive relations. Navier-Stokes equations and methods of solution. Sealing techniques. BMD_ENG 270-0 or consent of instructor.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 378-0 Transport Fundamentals (1 Unit)
description: Fundamental and biomedical applications of diffusive and convective heat and mass transfer. BMD_ENG 270-0 ; MATH 228-1 ; BMD_ENG 377-0 recommended.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 380-0 Medical Devices, Disease & Global Health (1 Unit)
description: Health systems and technologies to address health problems of the world's underserved populations, with special emphasis on developing countries.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 388-SA Health Systems Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to health systems in the context of disease burden with special emphasis in developing countries.  We examine healthcare systems, financing, data and analytics. The course focuses primarily on health-related issues confronting South Africa and the associated social and economic impact.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 389-SA Health Technology Management (1 Unit)
description: This course provides an introduction to formal concepts and methodologies used in support of health technology planning, assessment and adoption - and related decision making - as part of cost-effective healthcare delivery.  Open to participants in the Global Health Technologies Program only.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 390-1 Biomedical Engineering Design (1 Unit)
description: Open-ended team-designed projects in the medical devices arena. Systems approach requiring design strategy and concepts, including reliability, safety, ethics, economic analysis, marketing, FDA regulations, and patents. Written and oral reports. Pre-Requisites: BMD_ENG 207-0 , BMD_ENG 220-0 , BMD_ENG 270-0 , BMD_ENG 308-0 , BMD_ENG 309-0 , COMP_SCI 150 and two of the following: BMD_ENG 250-0 , BMD_ENG 271-0 , MAT_SCI 201-0 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 390-2 Biomedical Engineering Design (1 Unit)
description: Development of a design project initiated during the previous quarter. BMD_ENG 390-1 .

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 390-3 Biomedical Engineering Design (1 Unit)
description: Continuation of a design project; independent study. May not be repeated for credit. BMD_ENG 390-1 or BMD_ENG 390-2 ; consent of instructor.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 391-SA HealthCare Techology Innovation and Design (1 Unit)
description: Principles and practice of medical device design for the developing world.  Evaluation of user needs in the environment of under-resourced segments of South African health care system.  Validation and verification of engineering design solutions.  Open to participants in the Global Health Technologies Program only.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 395-0 Topics in Biomedical Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 396-0 Special Topics (0.5 Unit)
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis. BMD_ENG 397-0 Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering (0.5-1 Unit) Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 398-0 Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering (0.34 Unit)
description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering, Laboratory emphasis.

subject: BMD_ENG
title_units: BMD_ENG 399-0 Projects (1 Unit)
description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 301-0 Accounting (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to both financial and managerial accounting. Use of organizations' financial statements for making decisions. ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0 .

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 302-0 Marketing Management (1 Unit)
description: Basic principles and applications of marketing management. Marketing segmentation, target marketing, brand positioning, consumer behavior, channels strategy, pricing, advertising and promotion. ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0 .

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 303-0 Leadership in Organizations (1 Unit)
description: Social science tools for solving organizational problems and influencing individuals, groups, and organizations. Competitive decision making, reward system design, team building, strategic negotiation, political dynamics, corporate culture, and strategic organizational design. ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0 . Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 304-0 Corporate Finance (1 Unit)
description: Effects of time and uncertainty on valuation and decision making. Discounting techniques, stock and bond valuation, capital budgeting, firm valuation, capital asset pricing model, financial options. May not receive credit for both this course and ECON 360-1 . Not for students who have previously taken KELLG_FE 310-0 . ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0 ; STAT 210-0 or equivalent; MATH 218-1 or MATH 220-1 ; and BUS_INST 301-0 .

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 321-0 Business and Economic Institutions in Historical Perspective (1 Unit)
description: Factors affecting economic growth and challenges to achieving economic success. Organization of firms and financial markets; corporate governance; innovation; financial crises; income inequality; race and gender. ECON 201-0 and ECON 202-0 ; STAT 210-0 or equivalent; and MATH 218-1 or MATH 220-1 . Historical Studies Distro Area

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 331-0 Real Estate Finance & Investment (1 Unit)
description: An introduction to the fundamental concepts, principles, analytical methods and tools used for making investing and financing decisions regarding income producing properties. Topics covered include leases, cash flow-based real estate evaluation, property financing (debt), real estate private equity, and property taxation. ECON 201-0 , ECON 202-0 , STAT 210-0 or equivalent, BUS_INST 304-0 or equivalent.

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 394-LK Professional Linkage Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Content varies. Possible topics include entrepreneurship, investment banking, business ethics, global marketing, sports marketing, and nonprofit management. Prerequisites vary.

subject: BUS_INST
title_units: BUS_INST 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 100-0 Introduction to Calculus and Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: For participants in Bio&ChemEXCEL summer program. Introduction to calculus and general chemistry. Taken with BIOL_SCI 100-0 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 100-BR Introduction to Problem Solving in Chemistry (0.5 Unit)
description: For participants in Bridge I summer program. Developing facility with quantitative tools to solve problems in chemistry. MATH 100-BR and HUM 100-1-BR .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 105-7 College Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and introducing skills necessary to thriving at Northwestern. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 105-8 First-Year Writing Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and focused on the fundamentals of effective, college-level written communication. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 110-0 Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry (1.34 Units)
description: Solution strategies for traditional word problems and their application to basic chemistry quantitative problems: dimensional analysis, chemical equations, stoichiometry, limiting reagents.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 110-MG Mentored Study Program (0 Unit)
description: Study sessions facilitated by undergraduate peer leaders, for students enrolled in CHEM 110-0 . Meets weekly in small groups to collaboratively review material, solve practice problems, clarify concepts, and enhance study strategies. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 110-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: Quantitative Problem Solving in Chemistry (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 110-0 .  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 131-0 Fundamentals of Chemistry I (1 Unit)
description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, solutions and colligative properties. CHEM 110-0 (C- or better). Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 131-MG Mentored Study Program (0 Unit)
description: Study sessions facilitated by undergraduate peer leaders, for students enrolled in CHEM 131-0 . Meets weekly in small groups to collaboratively review material, solve practice problems, clarify concepts, and enhance study strategies. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 131-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: Fundamentals of Chemistry I (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 131-0 .  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 132-0 Fundamentals of Chemistry II (1 Unit)
description: Chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry. CHEM 131-0 , CHEM 141-0 (C- or better). Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 132-MG Mentored Study Program (0 Unit)
description: Study sessions facilitated by undergraduate peer leaders, for students enrolled in CHEM 132-0 . Meets weekly in small groups to collaboratively review material, solve practice problems, clarify concepts, and enhance study strategies. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 132-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: Fundamentals of Chemistry II (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 132-0 .  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 141-0 Fundamentals of Chemistry Laboratory I (0.34 Unit)
description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 131-0 . CHEM 110-0 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 142-0 Fundamentals of Chemistry Laboratory II (0.34 Unit)
description: SUMMER OFFERING - Lab fee. Must be taken concurrently with Chem 132-0.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 151-0 General Chemistry I (1 Unit)
description: Quantum mechanics, electronic structure, periodic properties of elements, chemical bonding, thermodynamics, gas laws, intermolecular forces, properties of solids and liquids, solutions and colligative properties. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 151-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: General Chemistry I (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 151-0 .  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 152-0 General Chemistry II (1 Unit)
description: Chemical equilibrium, aqueous solution equilibria, chemical kinetics, metals in chemistry and biology, oxidation-reduction reactions and electrochemistry. CHEM 151-0 , CHEM 161-0 (C- or better). Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 152-SG Peer-Guided Study Group: General Chemistry II (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 152-0 .  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 161-0 General Chemistry Laboratory I (0.34 Unit)
description: Chemical analysis of real samples using basic laboratory techniques including titration, colorimetric analysis, density measurements, and atomic spectroscopy. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 151-0 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 162-0 General Chemistry Laboratory II (0.34 Unit)
description: Chemistry laboratory techniques applied to materials science and nanotechnology, acid-base chemistry, and chemical kinetics. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 152-0 . CHEM 151-0 , CHEM 161-0 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 171-0 Advanced General Inorganic Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: Review of mole problems and stoichiometry; descriptive chemistry, elements, compounds, and inorganic reactions; gas laws; phase equilibria and colligative properties; chemical equilibrium; aqueous equilibria; topics in chemical bonding and molecular structure. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 181-0 . Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 172-0 Advanced General Physical Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: Thermodynamics and equilibrium; chemical kinetics and mechanism; electrochemistry; electronic structure of the atom and quantum theory; advanced topics in chemical bonding; coordination compounds; solid-state chemistry; nuclear chemistry. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 182-0 . CHEM 171-0 , CHEM 181-0 (C- or better); MATH 220-1 . Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 181-0 Advanced General Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory (0.34 Unit)
description: Laboratory techniques for studying chemical analysis and chemical reactions relevant to environmental or materials research. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 171-0 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 182-0 Advanced General Physical Chemistry Laboratory (0.34 Unit)
description: Study of physical chemistry (acid base chemistry, thermodynamics, etc.) in the laboratory. Planning, data collection, interpretation, and reporting on these experiments. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 172-0 . CHEM 171-0 , CHEM 181-0 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 201-0 Chemistry of Nature and Culture (1 Unit)
description: Chemistry for the nonscientist. Chemicals commonly encountered in everyday life. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-1 Organic Chemistry I (1 Unit)
description: Foundational concepts in organic chemistry will be introduced. Topics include structure and properties of common functional groups, acidity/basicity, conformational analysis, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds. CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0 , or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0 , or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); or qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-1 . Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-2 Organic Chemistry II (1 Unit)
description: Fundamental concepts in organic chemistry will be covered.  The topics will include important functional groups and will include:  nomenclature, structure, properties, and multistep synthesis. Reaction mechanisms for organic transformations will be presented, and synthesis strategies will be covered. CHEM 215-1 and CHEM 235-1 . Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-2 . Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-3 Organic Chemistry III (1 Unit)
description: Advanced concepts in modern organic chemistry will be introduced. The material will focus on recent developments in synthetic organic chemistry, including: concerted/pericyclic reactions, catalysis, green/environmental chemistry, automated synthesis, and combinatorial/screening methods. CHEM 215-2 and in CHEM 235-2 . Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-3 . Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-MG-1 Mentored Study Program (0 Unit)
description: Study sessions facilitated by undergraduate peer leaders, for students enrolled in CHEM 215-1 . Meets weekly in small groups to collaboratively review material, solve practice problems, clarify concepts, and enhance study strategies. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-MG-2 Mentored Study Program (0 Unit)
description: Study sessions facilitated by undergraduate peer leaders, for students enrolled in CHEM 215-2 . Meets weekly in small groups to collaboratively review material, solve practice problems, clarify concepts, and enhance study strategies. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-SG-1 Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry I (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-1 . Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-SG-2 Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry II (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-2 . Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 215-SG-3 Peer-Guided Study Group: Organic Chemistry III (0 Unit)
description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in CHEM 215-3 . Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 217-1 Accelerated Organic Chemistry I (1 Unit)
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. Basic concepts of structure, stereochemistry, and reactivity of organic compounds. The chemistry of hydrocarbons and alcohols. No P/N registration. CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0 , or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0 , or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or department placement. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 237-1 . Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 217-1 and 212-1. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 217-2 Accelerated Organic Chemistry II (1 Unit)
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. The chemistry of aromatic, carbonyl, and nitrogen compounds; characterization of organic substances by chemical and spectral methods; reaction mechanisms. No P/N registration. CHEM 217-1 and CHEM 237-1 (C- or better). Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 237-2 . Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 217-2 and 212-2. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 217-3 Accelerated Organic Chemistry III (1 Unit)
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. The chemistry of poly-functional compounds of biological and medicinal interest. Modern organic syn-thesis, bioorganic chemistry, and recent developments in organic chemistry. No P/N registration. CHEM 217-2 and CHEM 237-2 (C- or better). Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 235-3 . Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 217-3 and 212-3. Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 220-0 Introductory Instrumental  Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to basic laboratory techniques in analytical chemistry and spectroscopy. Topics include infrared and UV-visible spectroscopy, gas and liquid chromatography, elemental and thermal analysis, simple x-ray diffraction, error analysis, and literature searching techniques. CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0 , or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0 , or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 235-1 Organic Chemistry Lab I (0.34 Unit)
description: Standard laboratory techniques in organic chemistry will be covered. Techniques will focus on the isolation and purification of organic compounds as well as the use of spectroscopic methods to determine identity and purity. CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0 , or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0 , or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); or qualifying score on the Chemistry Placement Exam. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-1 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 235-2 Organic Chemistry Lab II (0.34 Unit)
description: Complete laboratory experiments focusing on standard synthetic organic chemistry will be conducted each week. Students will complete a prelab worksheet including stoichiometric calculations, prediction of reaction outcome, and identification of safety protocols. CHEM 215-1 and CHEM 235-1 . Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-2 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 235-3 Organic Chemistry Lab III (0.34 Unit)
description: Current laboratory practices for organic synthesis will be introduced. Reactions will include mechanistically complex multi-step process for the preparation of compounds related to topical themes from academic research and industrial chemistry. Synthetic targets will include complex small molecules, polymers, and molecules of biological relevance. CHEM 215-2 and in CHEM 235-2 . Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 217-3 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 237-1 Accelerated Organic Chemistry Laboratory I (0.34 Unit)
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. Molecular modeling, unknown identification by spectroscopic methods, and experimental techniques of modern chemistry emphasizing reactions of alkanes, alkenes, alkyl halides, alcohols, and carbonyls. CHEM 132-0 and CHEM 142-0 , or CHEM 152-0 and CHEM 162-0 , or CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better), or equivalent. Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 217-1 . Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 237-1 and 232-1.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 237-2 Accelerated Organic Chemistry Laboratory II (0.34 Unit)
description: Primarily for chemistry majors and students in ISP. Techniques of modern organic chemistry including NMR spectroscopy and reactions such as electrophilic aromatic substitution, esterification, Grignard reaction, aldol condensation, Robinson annulation, and Diels-Alder reaction. CHEM 217-1 and CHEM 237-1 (C- or better). Must be taken concurrently with CHEM 217-2 . Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 237-2 and 232-2.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 302-0 Principles of Inorganic Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: Topics in advanced inorganic chemistry. CHEM 302-0 and CHEM 402-0 are taught together. CHEM 333-0 or consent of instructor.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 303-0 Principles of Physical Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: An overview of advanced topics in physical chemistry. CHEM 303-0 and CHEM 403-0 are taught together. CHEM 342-1 and CHEM 342-2 and CHEM 342-3 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 305-0 Chemistry of Life Processes (1 Unit)
description: Topics in the chemistry and biochemistry of life processes. Taught with CHEM 405-0 . CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better); and 1 biochemistry course; or consent of instructor.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 306-0 Environmental Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: Topics in the physical chemistry of the environment. Taught with CHEM 406-0 . CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better); MATH 230-2 ; PHYSICS 135-1 and PHYSICS 135-2 ; or consent of instructor.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 307-0 Supramolecular Design of Materials and Nanostructures (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to frontier research at the interface of chemistry and materials science. CHEM 307-0 and CHEM 407-0 are taught together. CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 308-0 Design, Synthesis, and Applications of Nanomaterials (1 Unit)
description: Fabrication, chemical synthesis, assembly, and characterization of controlled-dimensionality materials, including metals, semiconductors, oxides, polymers, and mesoporous scaffolds. Interfacial phenomena and particle stability, nano forms of carbon, and material design. Taught with CHEM 408-0 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 309-0 Polymer Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: This course will cover the design and synthesis of polymers, including reaction mechanisms, characterization, and structure-property relationships. CHEM 309-0 is taught with CHEM 409-0 .   Prerequisites (for undergraduates only): CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better); and one of the following courses: CHEM 307-0 , CHEM 313-0 , CHEM 319-0 , CHEM 412-0 , or CHEM 415-0 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 310-1 Physical Organic Chemistry I (1 Unit)
description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of physical organic chemistry, including: molecular orbital theory, orbital symmetry and reactivity, conformational analysis and stereochemistry, stereoelectronic effects, intermolecular forces and solvation, transition state theory, free energy relationships and kinetic isotope effects, and reactive intermediates. CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 217-3 or equivalent to enroll.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 310-2 Physical Organic Chemistry II (1 Unit)
description: Expansion on the concepts and practices of physical organic chemistry including: orbital symmetry and reactivity, energy surfaces and Marcus theory, single-electron transfer reactions, solvent effects, nucleophilic and electrophilic reactivity, photochemistry and photocatalysis, organic electronic materials. CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 217-3 or equivalent. CHEM 310-1 strongly recommended.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 313-0 Advanced Organic Chemistry 1. Advanced concepts of organic reactivity and selectivity in synthesis. (1 Unit)
description: Strategies and tactics involved in complex target synthesis. Modern reaction classes as applied to chemical synthesis, coupled to in-depth discussion of the underlying key principles of synthesis design and execution, are covered in the class. Students will gain experience in problem solving, creative thinking, structural analysis and presentation skills. CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 314-0 Principles of Chemical Biology (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to using chemical principles in biology and medicine. Experimental techniques and experiments in chemical biology. Suitable for students in chemistry, engineering, and biology. Taught with CHEM 415-0 . CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better); and 1 quarter of biology; or consent of instructor.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 316-0 Medicinal Chemistry: the Organic Chemistry of Drug Design and Action (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to principles of drug design and mechanisms of drug action from a chemical viewpoint. Historical introduction, drug design and development, receptors, enzymes and enzyme inhibitors, DNA, drug metabolism, and prodrugs. CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 (C- or better); or consent of instructor.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 319-0 Advanced Organic Synthesis - Concepts and Applications (1 Unit)
description: Synthesis of natural products and other medicinally relevant organic compounds. Retrosynthetic analysis, substructure keying, and pattern recognition. Classic and modern organic reactions. Terpenes, alkaloids, polyketides, steroids, proteins, and pharmaceuticals. CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or 217-3 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 333-0 Inorganic Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: Descriptive chemistry of some important elements. Current concepts and models of chemical bonding.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 342-1 Thermodynamics (1 Unit)
description: Laws of applications of thermodynamics. Thermochemistry, chemical potentials, solution thermodynamics, nonideal gases. CHEM 132-0 or CHEM 152-0 or CHEM 172-0 or CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3 or CHEM 217-3 (C- or better); and MATH 230-1 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 342-2 Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy (1 Unit)
description: Quantum mechanics with emphasis on atomic and molecular electronic structure. Electronic, vibrational, rotational, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy. MATH 230-2 ; PHYSICS 135-1 and 135-2 ; and CHEM 342-1 .

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 342-3 Kinetics and Statistical Thermodynamics (1 Unit)
description: Chemical kinetics, including experimental techniques and theories of rate processes. Statistical mechanics, including Boltzmann distribution, partition functions, and applications to thermodynamics. CHEM 342-1 and CHEM 342-2 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 348-0 Physical Chemistry for ISP (1 Unit)
description: Gas laws and properties; kinetic theory; first, second, and third laws; phase equilibria; mixtures, phase diagrams, statistical thermodynamics, kinetics. CHEM 172-0 and CHEM 182-0 (C- or better); MATH 281-1 , MATH 281-2 , MATH 281-3 ; or consent of department.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 350-1 Advanced Laboratory 1 (1 Unit)
description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy: mass spectrometry, chromatography, NMR spectroscopy, and organic synthesis techniques. CHEM 220-0 ; and CHEM 215-3 or CHEM 212-3, and CHEM 235-3 (C- or better); or equivalent.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 350-2 Advanced Laboratory 2 (1 Unit)
description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy, polymer characterization methods, electrochemistry, x-ray crystallography, atomic spectroscopy, and inorganic synthesis techniques. CHEM 333-0 and CHEM 350-1 (C- or better) or equivalent.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 350-3 Advanced Laboratory 3 (1 Unit)
description: Advanced laboratory techniques in synthetic and analytical chemistry and spectroscopy: infrared and Raman spectroscopy, electronic spectroscopy, fast kinetics, organic and inorganic synthesis techniques in a self-guided project. CHEM 342-2 or equivalent and CHEM 350-2 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 393-0 Green Chemistry (1 Unit)
description: Practices of environmentally benign chemistry as applied to the chemical industry. Introduction to the concept and discipline of green chemistry; growth and expansion of the discipline in historical context from its origins in the early 1990s to the present. CHEM 215-2 or CHEM 217-2 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 398-0 Undergraduate Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Advanced work for superior students through supervised reading, research, and discussion.

subject: CHEM
title_units: CHEM 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: Faculty-directed research. Must be taken P/N for first 2 quarters. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page.
