subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 101-0 Getting to Know Chemical Engineering (0 Unit)
description: This survey course is an overview of the discipline of chemical engineering, and its undergraduate program at Northwestern. It is primarily targeted to first-years who are considering the major. We will discuss the most recent areas of research, career paths after graduation, and engineering ethics. Most course sessions will involve external speakers.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 190-0 Engineering of Chemical and Biological Processes (1 Unit)
description: Survey of engineering principles as they are applied to processes involving chemical and biological transformations. Examples from the chemical, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, food processing, electronics, and other industries. Impact of economics, ethics, and other nontechnical constraints.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 210-0 Analysis of Chemical Process Systems (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to process systems. Material balances and stoichiometry. Analysis of process system flow sheets. Introduction to departmental computing facilities. Basic numerical analysis. CHEM 132-0 , CHEM 152-0 , or CHEM 172-0 ; GEN_ENG 205-3 (may be taken concurrently).

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 211-0 Thermodynamics (1 Unit)
description: The first and second laws of thermodynamics. Entropy and equilibrium. Material and energy balances. Equations of state and properties of fluids. Solutions, phase equilibria, and chemical reactions. CHEM_ENG 210-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 212-0 Phase Equilibrium and Staged Separations (1 Unit)
description: Thermodynamic models of mixtures and phase equilibrium. Analysis and design of staged separation processes such as distillation, absorption, stripping, and extraction. CHEM_ENG 210-0 , CHEM_ENG 211-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 275-0 Molecular & Cell Biology for Engineers (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to cell and molecular biology concepts that provide the foundation for modern biotechnology and bioengineering. CHEM 132-0 , CHEM 152-0 , or CHEM 172-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 307-0 Kinetics and Reactor Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Chemical reaction kinetics with application to the design of chemical reactors. CHEM_ENG 210-0 , CHEM_ENG 211-0 , CHEM_ENG 321-0 , CHEM_ENG 322-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 312-0 Probability and Statistics for Chemical Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to probability theory and statistical methods necessary for analyzing the behavior of processes and experiments. Statistical tests for detecting significant changes in process parameters. MATH 220-1 , MATH 220-2 , MATH 228-1 , & MATH 228-2 (formerly listed as MATH 220-0, MATH 224-0, MATH 230-0, & MATH 234-0), or ES_APPM 252-1 & ES_APPM 252-2 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 321-0 Fluid Mechanics (1 Unit)
description: Derivation and applications of continuity and Navier-Stokes equations. Macroscopic mass, momentum, and energy balance. Dimensional analysis: friction factors in pipes and packed beds; drag coefficients. GEN_ENG 205-4 (C- or better).

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 322-0 Heat Transfer (1 Unit)
description: The differential equations of energy transport. Solutions for various applications. GEN_ENG 205-4 (C- or better); CHEM_ENG 321-0 recommended.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 323-0 Mass Transfer (1 Unit)
description: Diffusion and rate concepts; application to distillation, extraction, absorption, humidification, drying. CHEM_ENG 321-0 , CHEM_ENG 322-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 330-0 Molecular Engineering and Statistical Mechanics (1 Unit)
description: Basic statistical mechanics. Applications to thermodynamics, kinetics, and transport of various engineering systems, including frontier areas of chemical and biological engineering. Not open to students who have taken CHEM_ENG 406-0 , CHEM 342-3 , or PHYSICS 332-0 . CHEM_ENG 211-0 or another thermodynamics course; courses in probability and statistics, heat transfer, or other transport recommended.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 341-0 Dynamics and Control of Chemical and Biological Processes (1 Unit)
description: Dynamic behavior of chemical process components. Feedback control principles. CHEM_ENG 307-0 ; senior standing.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 342-0 Chemical Engineering Laboratory (1 Unit)
description: Operation and control of process equipment for the determination of operating data. Analysis and written presentation of results. CHEM_ENG 212-0 , CHEM_ENG 307-0 , CHEM_ENG 321-0 , CHEM_ENG 322-0 , CHEM_ENG 323-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 345-0 Process Optimization for Energy and Sustainability (1 Unit)
description: Modern techniques and application to the design and operation of chemical process systems. Steady-state and dynamic methods. Experimental search for the optimum.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 351-0 Process Economics, Design, & Evaluation (1 Unit)
description: Preliminary design of industrial processes for the production of chemical and allied products by the application of the engineering sciences and economics. CHEM_ENG 212-0 , CHEM_ENG 307-0 , CHEM_ENG 321-0 , CHEM_ENG 322-0 , CHEM_ENG 323-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 352-0 Chemical Engineering Design Projects (1 Unit)
description: Design of chemical and process plants applying the principles of unit operations, thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, and economics. Mechanical design and selection of chemical process equipment. CHEM_ENG 351-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 355-0 Chemical Product Design (1 Unit)
description: Properties and selection of chemicals for products from single-molecule pharmaceuticals to devices to manufactured products such as food and consumer goods.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 361-0 Introduction to Polymers (1 Unit)
description: Polymerization mechanisms and their relation to molecular structure, polymerization processes, and the mechanical properties of polymers, especially flow behavior. CHEM_ENG 211-0 or other thermodynamics course; CHEM 210-1.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 364-0 Chemical Processing and the Environment (1 Unit)
description: Application of chemical engineering fundamentals to environmental problems. Chemistry and mechanisms, chemical reaction and rate, and transport emphasized. Risk assessment and analysis revealed through case studies. CHEM_ENG 212-0 , CHEM_ENG 307-0 .

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 365-0 Sustainability, Technology, and Society (1 Unit)
description: Technical discussion of selected topics related to sustainability, sustainable development, global climate changes, natural and renewal resources and utilization, industrial ecology, eco-efficiency, technology related to sustainability such as biofuel, electrification of transportation, and water purification, and role of policy and business risk assessment. CHEM_ENG 210-0 or CIV_ENV 260-0 ).

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 367-0 Quantitative Methods in Life Cycle Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Lifecycle analysis (LCA) framework for environmental assessment of technology systems, focusing on modeling methods for systems mass and energy flows, process and input-output-based systems inventories, environmental impact analysis, and methods for robust engineering decisions. MECH_ENG 367-0 is taught with CHEM_ENG 367-0 ; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 372-0 Bionanotechnology (1 Unit)
description: Physical biology of the cell and its implications for nanotechnology, with a focus on the quantitative description of sizes, shapes, times, and energies at the nanoscale. MATH 228-1 (formerly listed as MATH 230-0).

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 373-0 Biotechnology and Global Health (1 Unit)
description: Recent advances in synthetic biology and genetic, metabolic, and tissue engineering. Design, development, and commercialization of healthcare technologies for countries in the developing world and the challenges of deploying preventative, diagnostic, and therapeutic products in these settings.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 375-0 Biochemical Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Modern biochemical engineering. Life sciences: microbiology, biochemistry, and molecular genetics. Metabolic stoichiometry, energetics, growth kinetics, transport phenomena in bioreactors, and product recovery. CHEM_ENG 307-0 , CHEM_ENG 323-0 , or consent of instructor.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 376-0 Principles of Synthetic Biology (1 Unit)
description: Overview of synthetic biology's foundations in the natural sciences and engineering and its applications in medicine, biotechnology, and green chemistry. How engineering driven approaches may be used to accelerate design-build-test loops required for reprogramming existing biological systems and constructing new ones. CHEM_ENG 275-0 or BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 (formerly BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0).

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 377-0 Bioseparations (1 Unit)
description: Downstream process in biotechnology. Separation and lysis of cells. Recovery of organelles and proteins. Protein separation and purification. CHEM_ENG 323-0 (may be taken concurrently); CHEM_ENG 275-0 or BIOL_SCI 201-0 or BIOL_SCI 202-0 (formerly BIOL_SCI 215-0 or BIOL_SCI 219-0).

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 378-0 Deconstructing Synthetic Biology – Biotechnology Case Studies Across Scales (1 Unit)
description: Synthetic biology uses concepts across STEM fields to reuse, repurpose and redesign biological systems to solve important global challenges. Here, we break down how synthetic biology solutions integrate concepts across five spatiotemporal scales—molecular, network, cell/cell-free systems, biological communities and societal—using case studies in sustainability, biomanufacturing and human health. The deconstruction approach enables students to better tackle scientific challenges.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 379-0 Computational Biology: Analysis and Design of Living Systems (1 Unit)
description: This course provides an introduction to fundamental principles and methods for computational and mathematical analysis of natural and engineered biological systems. Emphasis is placed upon understanding and designing biological systems based upon conceptual framings including multi-scale networks, dynamic control, genetic circuits, and biological programs.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 381-0 Practical Biological Imaging (1 Unit)
description: Theory and practice of biological microscopy in a lab setting; image acquisition, analysis, and the ethics of image manipulation.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 382-0 Regulatory Sciences in Biotechnology (1 Unit)
description: Course on topics at the intersection of science, engineering, and biotech regulatory compliance. Federal regulations for drug product development; regulatory compliance processes and organizational structure; interface between biotechnology processes and regulatory sciences; global harmonization of regulations; regulatory documentation.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 395-0 Special Topics in Chemical Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

subject: CHEM_ENG
title_units: CHEM_ENG 399-0 Projects (1 Unit)
description: Supervised investigation of a chemical engineering problem with submission of a final report. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 111-1 Chinese I (1 Unit)
description: First-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 111-2 Chinese I (1 Unit)
description: Second-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese. CHINESE 111-1 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 111-3 Chinese I (1 Unit)
description: Third-quarter course of the beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese. CHINESE 111-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 115-1 Chinese I - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 115-2 Chinese I - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese. CHINESE 115-1 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 115-3 Chinese I - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Chinese. CHINESE 115-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 121-1 Chinese II (1 Unit)
description: First-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency. CHINESE 111-3 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 121-2 Chinese II (1 Unit)
description: Second-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency. CHINESE 121-1 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 121-3 Chinese II (1 Unit)
description: Third-quarter course of the second-year Chinese sequence to further develop basic literacy and oral proficiency. CHINESE 121-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 125-1 Chinese II - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing. CHINESE 115-3 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 125-2 Chinese II - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing. CHINESE 125-1 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 125-3 Chinese II - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate-level sequence with emphasis on reading and writing. CHINESE 125-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 211-1 Chinese III (1 Unit)
description: First-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency. CHINESE 121-3 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 211-2 Chinese III (1 Unit)
description: Second-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency. CHINESE 211-1 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 211-3 Chinese III (1 Unit)
description: Third-quarter course of the intermediate-level sequence to further develop literacy and oral proficiency. CHINESE 211-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 212-0 Chinese in Business Practice 1 (1 Unit)
description: Basic business Chinese focused on professional settings. For students interested in using business-related texts to learn Chinese or aspiring to China-focused careers. CHINESE 125-2 , CHINESE 211-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 215-1 Chinese III - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: First-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing. CHINESE 125-3 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 215-2 Chinese III - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: Second-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing. CHINESE 215-1 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 215-3 Chinese III - Accelerated (1 Unit)
description: Third-quarter course of the accelerated intermediate toward advanced-level sequence with emphasis on formal speaking and writing. CHINESE 215-2 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 311-1 Chinese IV: Formal Speaking (1 Unit)
description: Development of skills in speaking formal Chinese. CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0 , or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 311-2 Chinese IV: Formal Writing (1 Unit)
description: Development of skills in writing formal Chinese. CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0 , or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 311-3 Chinese IV: Formal Reading (1 Unit)
description: Development of skills in reading different types of authentic Chinese works. CHINESE 211-3 or CHINESE 212-0 , or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 312-1 Chinese in Business Practice 2 (1 Unit)
description: Training for professional tasks using Chinese. Especially for students who completed CHINESE 212-0 or aspire to China-focused careers or to becoming multi-proficient business professionals. CHINESE 125-3 , CHINESE 211-3 , CHINESE 212-0 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 312-2 Multinational Corporations in China (1 Unit)
description: Training in business reading skills, with a focus on case studies, and speaking/writing skills for discussing business topics professionally. Designed for students interested in China's economic development and using Chinese in their careers. CHINESE 125-3 , CHINESE 211-3 , CHINESE 212-0 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 315-1 Chinese IV - Accelerated: Formal Writing and Public Speaking (1 Unit)
description: Development of academic writing and speaking in Chinese. CHINESE 215-3 ; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1 , CHINESE 311-2 , CHINESE 311-3 , CHINESE 312-1 , CHINESE 312-2 .

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 315-2 Chinese IV - Accelerated: Advanced Reading and Writing (1 Unit)
description: Development of academic reading and writing in Chinese. CHINESE 215-3 ; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1 , CHINESE 311-2 , CHINESE 311-3 , CHINESE 312-1 , CHINESE 312-2 .

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 315-3 Chinese IV  - Accelerated: Media & Society (1 Unit)
description: Development of skills in reading primary sociocultural sources. CHINESE 215-3 ; or in three of the following: CHINESE 311-1 , CHINESE 311-2 , CHINESE 311-3 , CHINESE 312-1 , CHINESE 312-2 .

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 320-0 Chinese V: Special Topics in Advanced Chinese (1 Unit)
description: Standalone topics course using films, audiovisual materials, and texts in primary sources to develop ability to analyze diverse textual logic, language patterns, and cultural features. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. CHINESE 315-1 , CHINESE 315-2 , CHINESE 315-3 or equivalent.

subject: CHINESE
title_units: CHINESE 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Chinese. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 101-0 Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering (0 Unit)
description: In this seminar course we discuss the grand challenges facing society in the coming decades, and how Civil and Environmental Engineers are meeting these challenges.  Seminars will focus on key CE and EE topics, the CE & EE curricula at NU, and the career paths of recent CE & EE graduates. CIV_ENV 195-0 Introductory Course in Civil and Environmental Engineering (0-1 Unit) Introductory-level special topics courses in civil and environmental engineering. 195 is similar to CIV_ENV 395-0 but intended for first and second-year students.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 201-0 Engineering Possibilities: Decision Science in the Age of Smart Technologies (1 Unit)
description: Define challenges facing cities, and learn how to critically evaluate different solutions, ranging from traditional to innovative. Foster critical thinking about problem definitions along with the definition of metrics that represent desirable (and undesirable) outcomes in urban systems.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 202-0 Biological and Ecological Principles (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of biology - including cell biology, genetics, and biochemistry - and ecology - including biological interactions, microbial ecology - and biogeochemical cycling as they apply to natural and engineered systems. Bioinformatics tools necessary for analyzing biological and ecological data. MATH 220-2 ; CHEM 131-0 , CHEM 151-0 , or CHEM 171-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 203-0 Earth in the Anthropocene (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of Earth system science and their connections to the need for humans to develop food, water, energy and infrastructure systems that has led to transformation of the Earth's surface and of its atmosphere. MATH 220-2 ; CHEM 131-0 , CHEM 151-0 , or CHEM 171-0 is highly recommended. Natural Sciences Distro Area

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 205-0 Economics and Finance for Engineers (1 Unit)
description: Principles of corporate finance; financial decisions of firms; value; risk and return; investment and capital budgeting decisions under certainty and uncertainty; performance evaluation. May not be taken for credit with or after KELLG_FE 310-0 . MATH 220-1 ; basic understanding of probability and economics recommended.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 216-0 Mechanics of Materials I (1 Unit)
description: Analytical and experimental study of stresses and deformations and their application to the design of machine and structural elements subjected to static, dynamic, and repeated loads. GEN_ENG 205-2 or GEN_ENG 206-2 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 220-0 Structural Art (1 Unit)
description: Learn how to interpret and understand the built environment through an examination of the history of structural engineering as a creative art, with particular emphasis on technical, visual, and social analysis and critique of bridges, buildings, and designers.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 221-0 Theory of Structures I (1 Unit)
description: Deflections of structures, energy concepts, idealization of structures, truss analysis, column stability, and influence lines. Introduction to indeterminate truss and frame analyses, slope-deflection analysis, and moment distribution. Portal method. CIV_ENV 216-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 250-0 Earth Surface Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Fundamental properties and behavior of soils as engineering materials. Origin of soils through the properties of soil components to the strength, permeability, and deformation of soil masses. MECH_ENG 241-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 260-0 Environmental Systems and Processes (1 Unit)
description: Basic engineering principles required for the design, operation, analysis, and modeling of both natural and engineered systems and their application to major issues facing human and environmental health of ecosystems. Corequisite: MATH 220-2 ; CHEM 131-0 , CHEM 151-0 , or CHEM 171-0 highly recommended.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 280-1 Architectural Engineering & Design Seminar I (0 Unit)
description: First course in the AED seminar series.  Students will learn from practicing architects and engineers, and will also conduct independent studies culminating in their own seminars to the class.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 280-2 Architectural Engineering & Design Seminar II (0 Unit)
description: Second course in the AED seminar series.  Students will learn from practicing architects and engineers, and will also conduct independent studies culminating in their own seminars to the class.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 280-3 Architectural Engineering & Design Seminar III (0 Unit)
description: Third course in the AED seminar series.  Students will learn from practicing architects and engineers, and will also conduct independent studies culminating in their own seminars to the class.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 295-0 Introductory topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Intermediate-level study of topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 301-1 Professional Development Seminar I (0.34 Unit)
description: Case study in engineering ethics, with discussion of topics in professional development and lifelong learning.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 301-2 Professional Development Seminar II (0 Unit)
description: Preparation for the Fundamentals of Engineering (FE) exam.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 302-0 Engineering Law (1 Unit)
description: The American legal system from an engineer's perspective. Socratic-method analysis of statutory and case law. Contract, patent, corporation, antitrust, property, and environmental law. Torts, product liability, and arbitration.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 303-0 Environmental Law and Policy (1 Unit)
description: An introduction to important aspects of environmental law and policy. Covers a wide range of environmental topics, with a focus on major federal environmental statutes.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 304-0 Civil and Environmental Engineering Systems Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Quantitative techniques to develop descriptive and prescriptive models that support efficient planning and management of civil and environmental engineering systems. MATH 220-2 or equivalent.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 306-0 Uncertainty Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Probability, statistics, and decision theory. Discrete and continuous random variables, marginal and conditional distributions, moments, statistical model selection and significance tests, hypothesis testing, and elementary Bayesian decision theory. Application to problems in soil mechanics, water resources, transportation, and structures.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 308-0 Environmental Justice (1 Unit)
description: This course will examine evidence that there is not equal environmental protection in this country and analyze why this inequality exists. Course participants will review evidence of environmental injustice, with attention to perspectives of grassroots organizations, the U.S. EPA, and businesses. The course will explore why civil and human rights have become important aspects of environmental protection activities worldwide.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 309-0 Climate and Energy - Law and Policy (1 Unit)
description: This course is a survey of the major laws that regulate the acquisition of energy resources, the conversion of energy resources into usable energy, the energy transmission and transportation infrastructure and the climate change implications of these activities.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 314-0 Organic Geochemistry (1 Unit)
description: The sources and fates of organic matter in the natural environment; global cycling of organic carbon; applications to the study of modern and ancient environments. Taught with EARTH 314-0 ; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 317-0 Biogeochemistry (1 Unit)
description: Cycling of biogenic elements (C, N, S, Fe, Mn) in surficial environments. Emphasis on microbial processes and isotopic signatures.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 320-0 Structural Analysis--Dynamics (1 Unit)
description: Single and multiple degree-of-freedom systems subjected to periodic, seismic, and general loadings. Time-history analysis of linear and nonlinear systems. Design methods for earthquakes. CIV_ENV 221-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 321-0 Concrete Properties (1 Unit)
description: Concrete as a composite material; relationship between constitutive laws and microstructure; failure theories; fracture; fatigue; strain rate effects; destructive and nondestructive testing; creep and shrinkage; chemistry of cement hydration; admixtures; aggregates; proportioning; new materials.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 323-0 Structural Steel Design (1 Unit)
description: Rational basis of structural design. Design approach for structural-steel components of a building system. CIV_ENV 216-0 ; CIV_ENV 221-0 or equivalent.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 325-0 Reinforced Concrete (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of reinforced concrete theory and design. Analysis and design of beams, slabs, and columns. Concurrent familiarization with current building codes, specifications, and practices. CIV_ENV 221-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 326-0 Engineering Forensics (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to failure analysis and forensic engineering to describe how these investigative procedures contribute to regulations, engineering design, safety principles, and the economic aspects of structure engineering. CIV_ENV 221-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 327-0 Finite Element Methods in Mechanics (1 Unit)
description: Development of finite elements from variational principles and application to static stress analysis. Introduction to techniques for transient and generalized field problems. Computer implementation of finite element techniques. Taught with MECH_ENG 327-0 ; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 328-0 Computational Forensics and Failure Analysis (1 Unit)
description: The course will cover the use of the scientific method for accident investigation, hypothesis development, and the use of the finite element method to analyze the root cause of a failure. Practical application problems for both civil and mechanical structures will be analyzed using commercial finite element codes (Abaqus, Hypermesh, LS-Dyna) Prerequiste: CIV_ENV 327-0 or MECH_ENG 327-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 330-0 Engineering Project Management (1 Unit)
description: Techniques for coordinating decisions and actions of various parties in the design and construction of civil and environmental engineering projects. Delivery systems; preconstruction services; project planning; cost control and value engineering; bidding.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 332-10 Building Construction Estimating (1 Unit)
description: Estimation of cost at different stages of design; conceptual estimating and quantity takeoff of various elements, such as materials, labor, and equipment. CIV_ENV 330-0 ; consent of instructor.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 336-10 Project Scheduling (1 Unit)
description: Project planning, scheduling, and control using CPM arrow and precedence networks; resource allocation and resource leveling; earned value analysis; linear scheduling; PERT, CPM in dispute resolution and litigation, computer scheduling. CIV_ENV 330-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 340-0 Hydraulics and Hydrology (1 Unit)
description: Civil and environmental engineering applications of fluid mechanics. Turbulent flow in pipes and rivers, pipe and river networks, and open channels. MECH_ENG 241-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 346-0 Ecohydrology (1 Unit)
description: Interactions between water and ecosystems in freshwater, terrestrial, and urban environments. Feedbacks between ecological and hydrological processes. Engineering of ecosystems such as constructed wetlands, green roofs, and other green infrastructure for resilient and sustainable water management. CIV_ENV 361-1 or graduate standing.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 352-0 Foundation Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Application of soil mechanics to analysis and design of foundations and embankments. Settlement of structures, bearing capacities of shallow and deep foundations, earth pressures on retaining structures, and slope stability. CIV_ENV 250-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 353-0 Energy Geostructures & Geosystems (1 Unit)
description: This course focuses on energy geostructures and geosystems: novel earth-contact technologies that provide renewable energy supply and structural support to any built environment. The course comprises theoretical and practical sessions. The theoretical sessions expand on the analysis and design of such technologies from energy, geotechnical and structural perspectives. The practical sessions simulate an actual design project of energy geostructures.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 357-0 Terramechanics (1 Unit)
description: Problems defined by the interaction between machines and terrain—or by organisms and terrain—are ubiquitous on Earth, and they are beginning to play important roles elsewhere as we explore, exploit, and perhaps eventually occupy the moon and other planets. While aspects of these problems are understood, much remains to be learned in the field of terramechanics.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 361-1 Environmental Microbiology (1 Unit)
description: Basic principles and practical applications of microbiology to environmental issues, such as microbial contamination, degradation of organic contaminants, production of alternative fuels, and global climate change.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 361-2 Public & Environmental Health (1 Unit)
description: Current problems in public and environmental health, such as the worldwide burden of major infectious diseases, emergence of new pathogens, and environmental reservoirs of infectious organisms. CIV_ENV 361-1 or consent of instructor.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 364-0 Sustainable Water Systems (1 Unit)
description: An overview of the engineered water cycle focusing the fundamental principles as well as the design and assessment methods for physical, chemical and biological treatment unit processes for drinking water treatment, used water treatment and reuse, and emerging issues such as the energy-food-water nexus. CIV_ENV 260-0 , MECH_ENG 241-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 365-0 Environmental Laboratory (1 Unit)
description: Chemical and microbiological aspects of environmental engineering and science are explored through an integrated laboratory course. CIV_ENV 367-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 366-0 Dynamics in Chemical Transport and Reaction (1 Unit)
description: Application of environmental engineering fundamentals to evaluate, model, and develop engineering solutions for different environmental contamination scenarios.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 367-0 Chemical Processes in Aquatic Systems (1 Unit)
description: Chemical principles for understanding and predicting the chemical composition and evolution of natural waters using an equilibrium approach. Applications to environmental issues such as metal speciation and toxicity, ocean acidification, carbon storage. BMD_ENG 250-0 or CHEM_ENG 211-0 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 368-0 Sustainability: The City (1 Unit)
description: Exploration of the issues that motivate the design and engineering of sustainable resource use and development.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 370-0 Emerging Organic Contaminants (1 Unit)
description: Fundamental molecular processes that govern the fate and transformation of emerging organic contaminants in natural and engineered environmental systems.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 371-0 Introduction to Transportation Planning and Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Analysis and design of solutions to transportation problems; introduction to selected operations research and statistical analysis techniques; use of case studies in urban transportation, intercity passenger transport, and freight movements.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 376-0 Transportation System Operations (1 Unit)
description: Traffic-flow theory; vehicle and human factors, capacity analysis, intersection performance and control; management and control of arterial streets and networks; neighborhood traffic restraint, urban transit operations. Operations concepts and theories applied to actual problems through laboratory practice.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 377-0 Choice Modelling in Engineering (1 Unit)
description: "This course focuses on the theory and practice of survey design, data and analysis. In this course students will learn the theories and scientific debates around the design, ad- ministration and analysis of various types of behavioral data-collection methods."

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 382-1 Capstone Design I (0.5 Unit)
description: Culminating team-based design experience in civil and environmental engineering, with an overview of the function, design, and operations of modern infrastructure systems.  Part 1 of 2-course sequence.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 382-2 Capstone Design II (0.5 Unit)
description: Culminating team-based design experience in civil and environmental engineering, with an overview of the function, design, and operations of modern infrastructure systems.  Part 2 of 2-course sequence. CIV_ENV 382-1 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 385-1 Architectural Engineering and Design 1: Fundamentals (1 Unit)
description: Architectural engineering and design studios: architectural history, case studies in design, construction and management of buildings, and drawing and model building. Fundamental studio: basic architectural and structural design of a simple building project.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 385-2 Architectural Engineering & Design 2: Intermediate (1 Unit)
description: Architectural engineering and design studios: architectural history, case studies in design, construction and management of buildings, and drawing and model building. Intermediate studio: architectural and structural design of a building project with multiple requirements. CIV_ENV 385-1 and junior standing in engineering; or consent of instructor.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 385-3 Architectural Engineering & Design 3: Advanced Studio (1 Unit)
description: Architectural engineering and design studios: architectural history, case studies in design, construction and management of buildings, and drawing and model building. Advanced studio: architectural and structural design of a large, complex building project. CIV_ENV 385-2 and junior standing in engineering; or consent of instructor.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 386-0 High Performance Architectural Design (1 Unit)
description: Elements of high performance building design and to explore the various matrics used to analyze the relationship between the structure and function of various design alternatives.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 387-0 Design of Sustainable Urban Developments (1 Unit)
description: Design high performing neighborhoods, districts and communities that incorporate principles of density, diversity and flexibility around the "operating system of nature". CIV_ENV 386-0 , senior standing, consent of instructor; recommend CIV_ENV 385-1 , CIV_ENV 385-2 , and CIV_ENV 385-3 .

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 388-1 Building Science I: Fundamentals for Sustainable Buildings (1 Unit)
description: The course is the first of a two-part series focusing on Building Science. This course aims to provide the fundamental knowledge of the physics related to buildings, focusing on heat and mass transfer, moisture, and the energy consumed in buildings to guarantee the comfort of their occupants.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 388-2 Building Science II: Application for Sustainable Buildings (1 Unit)
description: This course enriches and applies the concepts learned in CIV_ENV 388-1 . The course comprises both theoretical and practical sessions. Theoretical sessions introduce the environmental factors affecting occupants' comfort inside buildings. Practical sessions focus on the design of a virtual project, with calculations related to energy consumption and visual and thermal parameters with the help of computer software.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 395-0 Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engrg (1 Unit)
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty and approved by the department.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 398-1 Community-based Design 1 (1 Unit)
description: Yearlong participation in two-or three-person team projects involving research, analysis, and/or design in the solution of environmental problems affecting primarily lower-income communities. Grade assigned only on completion of both units.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 398-2 Community-based Design 2 (1 Unit)
description: Yearlong participation in two-or three-person team projects involving research, analysis, and/or design in the solution of environmental problems affecting primarily lower-income communities. Grade assigned only on completion of both units.

subject: CIV_ENV
title_units: CIV_ENV 399-0 Projects (1 Unit)
description: Special studies under faculty direction. Credit to be arranged. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 101-7 College Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and introducing skills necessary to thriving at Northwestern. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 101-8 First-Year Writing Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and focused on the fundamentals of effective, college-level written communication. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 110-0 A Study of Scientific Vocabulary Through Classical Roots (1 Unit)
description: Greek and Latin etymology in the vocabulary of the sciences. Designed primarily for science or medical students.

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 210-0 The World of Homer (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to the history and material culture of Iron Age Greece. Society, economy, art, and archaeology of the Greek world that gave rise to the Homeric epic. CLASSICS 210-0 and HUM 205-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses. Ethics  Values Distro Area Historical Studies Distro Area Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 211-0 Greek History and Culture: From Homer to Alexander the Great (1 Unit)
description: An introduction to the history, culture, and peoples of the ancient Greek world from the age of Homer (c. 7th century BCE) to Alexander the Great (323 BCE). Daily life; political, social, artistic, and intellectual developments. Special attention paid to Athenian democracy as well as the politics of other city-states, including Sparta. Primary sources include texts, art, and archaeology. Ethics  Values Distro Area Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 212-0 Rome: Culture and Empire (1 Unit)
description: Development and character of the Roman Republic and Empire, emphasizing political and social institutions. Roman origins of Europe's politics, religion, literature, and ideas. Ethics  Values Distro Area Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 245-0 Classics and the Cinema (1 Unit)
description: Analysis of how literary and social/political assumptions intersect in the reception of two related dramatic forms, one originating in 5th century Greece, the other in 20th century United States. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 250-0 Literatures of the Ancient World (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to ancient Mediterranean literatures through study of thematically related texts from various cultures and periods and to interpretive techniques and debates about them. Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 260-0 Classical Mythology (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to Greek and Roman traditional narratives. Emphasis on the social, political, and religious values that they engage. Ethics  Values Distro Area Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 310-0 Archaeology of the Ancient Mediterranean (1 Unit)
description: Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic. Recent topics: The Amazons - Warrior Women of Greek Myth and History; The Archaeology of Pompeii, Herculaneum, and Stabiae. Advanced Expression Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 311-SA On-Site Archaeology of the Ancient Mediterranean (1 Unit)
description: Study of Greco-Roman archaeological sites and objects conducted on site as part of the study abroad program, Athens: Ancient Culture and Modern City. Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 314-0 Topics in Ancient Science and Technology (1 Unit)
description: This course introduces students to the origins and histories of today's physical and quantitative sciences. Students gain understanding not only of the ways in which scientific knowledge has been generated and transmitted from the ancient past to the present, but also of the specific technical and quantitative methodologies through which the sciences have been practiced. Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 320-0 Greek and Roman History (1 Unit)
description: Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic. Recent topics: Sophokles and Athens, The Foundation of Rome through Legends and Objects. Advanced Expression Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 321-SA On-Site Greek and Roman History (1 Unit)
description: Study of Greco-Roman history conducted on site as part of the study abroad program, Athens: Ancient Culture and Modern City. Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 330-0 Ancient Economy (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to the preindustrial economy of the Roman Empire, highlighting its difference from postindustrial economies. Farming, transportation, demography, urbanism, technology, trade, and economic growth. Advanced Expression Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 340-0 Greek and Roman Drama (1 Unit)
description: Analysis of key works of ancient drama, chiefly tragedy and comedy; their material setting in the Greco-Roman Mediterranean; ancient drama's literary and performance aspects and social, political, and economic contexts. Advanced Expression Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 350-0 Greek and Latin Literature (1 Unit)
description: Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic. Recent topics include Love in Antiquity, Roman Comedy, and Roman Literature and Imperialism. Advanced Expression Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 360-0 Origins of Greek Democracy (1 Unit)
description: Emergence of the world's first democracies in archaic Greece, 750-460 BCE. Topics include the rise of the city-state, tyranny, Sparta, the effects of military reform, the invention of written law, and the development and consequences of democratic ideology. Historical Studies Distro Area Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 370-0 Greek and Roman Religion (1 Unit)
description: History and analysis of pagan religions of Greece and Rome and religions of the Roman Empire. Literary and material evidence; ancient and modern theories about ancient religions. Ethical and Evaluative Thinking Foundational Disci Ethics  Values Distro Area

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 380-0 Classical Reception Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic. This course focuses on how Greek and Roman sources (texts, images, material objects, figures, practices) have been utilized by post-antiquity actors in a variety of media, such as art, architecture, literature, music, cinema, theater, popular culture, etc. to make meaning in and for their own times (later-antiquity to contemporary times). Advanced Expression Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 390-0 Topics in Greco-Roman Civilization (1 Unit)
description: Content varies; may be repeated for credit with different topic. Recent topics: Materiality of Art and Archaeology of Roman Metals, Comparative Approaches to Ancient Empires.

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 395-0 Research Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Fundamental research skills through hands-on learning, and in-class work on an individual project. Students will learn how to use reference tools, allowing them to search, analyze and interpret literary texts, inscriptions, papyri and visual material. Course reflects current developments in Classics, and emphasizes digital approaches. Required for the major.

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 397-0 Exhibiting Antiquity: The Culture and Politics of Display (1 Unit)
description: Examination of the construction of Mediterranean antiquity through modes of reception since 1750. Analysis of programs of collecting and display and the intersection of institutional and scholarly agendas. ART_HIST 318-0 , CLASSICS 397-0 and HUM 397-0 taught together; may receive credit for only 1 of these courses. Historical Studies Distro Area Interdisciplinary Distro - See Rules Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: CLASSICS
title_units: CLASSICS 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: Individual program of study under the direction of a faculty member. For advanced students only. subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 100-SW Comm Foundations: Theory and Practice (0.5 Unit)
description: An introduction to communication as a dynamic process shaped by multiple factors (e.g., culture, interpretative practices, cognitive and behavioral patterns, identity formation and maintenance, power relationships). Students develop their critical awareness of this process and its relevance for their own social, civic, and professional lives through experimentation with a range of media and communication competencies (e.g., storytelling, performance, public speaking, textual analysis). Offered only in the summer for first-year students.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 101-0 SoC First Year Seminar: Interdisciplinary Topics in Communication Arts & Sciences (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to the study of human communication and expression through the interdisciplinary lenses of speech and hearing sciences, social scientific and humanistic studies of media, performance, film production and storytelling. Seminars are taught by teams of 2-3 faculty from the School of Communication’s five departments and six undergraduate programs. Restricted to SoC first-year and transfer students. SOC First-Year Seminar

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 300-0 School of Communication EPICS Internship Analysis (0 Unit)
description: Asynchronous, online course for School of Communication students who intern 8-40 hours per week with employers throughout the world. Requires the submission of a Handshake application, midterm assessment and final evaluation. Students should consult their academic advisor before applying.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 325-0 School of Communication EPICS Internship Seminar (0.25 Unit)
description: Course for School of Communication students who intern 8-40 hours per week with employers throughout the world. Requires the submission of a Handshake application, participation in an asynchronous, online course, midterm assessment and final evaluation. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic advisor before applying. CMN 340-0 School of Communication EPICS Internship Seminar (1-4 Units) Course for School of Communication students who intern 8-40 hours per week for employers throughout the world. Requires the submission of a Handshake application, participation in a weekly seminar course, midterm assessment and final evaluation. May be subject to internship course-credit limits; students should consult their academic advisor before applying.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 350-0 Global Media & Communications Seminar (GMCS) (1 Unit)
description: The Global Media & Communications Seminar (GMCS) features a combination of lectures and employer site visits that allow students to develop an understanding of and gain exposure to the global media and communications industries. This program allows students to engage with prominent industry professionals in the field and NU/LSE faculty in the classroom, all while exploring and touring the city of London. This program is open to School of Communication undergraduate majors only.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 370-0 Module Capstone (0 Unit)
description: Projects and co-curricular activities associated with a School of Communication module. In this 0-credit course, students who enrolled in a module complete an integrative capstone project, as well as any co-curricular activities associated with the relevant module.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 396-0 Student Organized Seminar (1 Unit)

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 398-1 SoC Capstone: Lecture (0.5 Unit)
description: SoC Capstone is a culminating school-wide requirement that empowers students to holistically reflect upon what they have learned and how they have grown through their experiences of coursework, internships, research, independent studies, employment, personal experience, creative and co-curricular activities. This self-reflection helps students understand their strengths and areas for future development. The requirement can be satisfied by a number of SoC and NU undergraduate courses (including CMN 398) that meet capstone learning objectives. Qualifying capstone courses also require students to relate their knowledge and skills to their post-graduation transition to potential employment or further educational pursuits.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 398-2 SoC Capstone: Lab (0.5 Unit)
description: The SoC Capstone lab course is a culminating experience where students will gain exposure to tools and techniques essential for navigating the complexities of a specific field aligned with an EPICS career community. They will also hone their ability to concisely convey the value of their Northwestern experience. This course will integrate and advance portfolio creation and provide students the opportunity to engage with School of Communication (SoC) alumni, industry leaders, and career professionals.

subject: CMN
title_units: CMN 399-0 Indep Study (1 Unit)
description: © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 110-0 Introduction to Cognitive Science (1 Unit)
description: Become familiar with and invested in cognitive science research, focusing on big themes in the study of the mind and mental representation, exemplified by interdisciplinary work conducted at Northwestern University. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 202-0 Evaluating Evidence (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to evaluation of qualitative and quantitative evidence across science, politics, society, health, education, and industry. POLI_SCI 212-0 and COG_SCI 202-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses. Empirical and Deductive Reasoning Foundational Dis Formal Studies Distro Area Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 207-0 Introduction to Cognitive Modeling (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to artificial intelligence and cognitive science. Fundamental questions concerning thinking, language understanding, analogy, commonsense reasoning, education, emotions and consciousness. Formal Studies Distro Area Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 210-0 Language and the Brain (1 Unit)
description: The study of language and its biological basis from linguistic, psychological, and neuroscientific perspectives. Natural Sciences Distro Area Natural Sciences Foundational Discipline

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 211-0 Learning, Representation & Reasoning (1 Unit)
description: Interdisciplinary study of the nature of the mind with emphasis on learning, representation, and reasoning. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 220-0 Selected Topics in Cognitive Science (1 Unit)
description: Topics in cognitive science. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 345-0 Presenting Ideas & Data (1 Unit)
description: Understanding principles of cognitive psychology, data visualization, and graphic design to present ideas and data in an engaging, clear, and memorable manner. PSYCH 345-0 and COG_SCI 345-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses. Advanced Expression Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 366-0 Cognitive Science Proseminar (1 Unit)
description: Seminar focused on current trends in cognitive science research and discussions with Northwestern cognitive science faculty. For cognitive science majors/minors or with consent of instructor.

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 398-1 Senior Thesis Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Independent research for a senior thesis under the direction of department faculty. By invitation only.

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 398-2 Senior Thesis Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Independent research for a senior thesis under the direction of department faculty. By invitation only.

subject: COG_SCI
title_units: COG_SCI 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: Faculty-directed research.
