description: Divisibility and prime numbers. Congruences. Quadratic reciprocity. Diophantine equations. MATH 228-1 or MATH 230-1 or MATH 281-1 or MATH 285-2 or MATH 290-2 or MATH 291-2 or ES_APPM 252-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 336-2 Introduction to the Theory of Numbers (1 Unit)
description: Topics in analytic and algebraic number theory. MATH 336-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 340-0 Geometry (1 Unit)
description: Axioms for Euclidean geometry. Non-Euclidean geometry. Projective geometry. Introduction of coordinate systems from the axioms. Quadrics. Erlangen program. Introduction to plane algebraic curves. MATH 300-0 or MATH 291-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 342-0 Introduction to Differential Geometry (1 Unit)
description: Differential geometry of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional space: curves, regular surfaces, the Gauss map, and additional topics as time permits. MATH 226-0 or MATH 281-2 ; and MATH 228-2 or MATH 230-2 or MATH 234-0 (former) or MATH 281-2 or MATH 285-3 or MATH 290-3 or MATH 291-3 or ES_APPM 252-2 ; and MATH 240-0 or MATH 281-3 or MATH 285-1 or MATH 290-1 or MATH 291-1 or GEN_ENG 205-1 or GEN_ENG 206-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 344-1 Introduction to Topology (1 Unit)
description: Topological spaces, continuity, connectedness, compactness, countability and separation axioms. MATH 320-1 or MATH 321-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 344-2 Introduction to Topology (1 Unit)
description: The fundamental group. Classification of covering spaces. Additional topics as permits. MATH 344-1 , and either MATH 330-1 or MATH 331-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 351-0 Fourier Analysis and Boundary Value Problems (1 Unit)
description: Fourier series with applications to partial differential equations arising in physics and engineering. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 351-0 and any of MATH 381-0 , MATH 360-2 , or ES_APPM 311-2. MATH 250-0 or MATH 281-3 or MATH 360-1 or GEN_ENG 206-4 or GEN_ENG 206-4 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 353-0 Qualitative Theory of Differential Equations (1 Unit)
description: Qualitative theory of ordinary differential equations: linear systems, phase portraits, periodic solutions, stability theory, Lyapunov functions, and chaos. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 353-0 and MATH 360-2 . MATH 250-0 or MATH 281-3 or MATH 360-1 or GEN_ENG 205-4 or GEN_ENG 206-4 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 354-0 Chaotic Dynamical Systems (1 Unit)
description: Chaotic phenomena in deterministic discrete dynamical systems, primarily through iteration of functions of one variable. MATH 240-0 or MATH 281-3 or MATH 285-1 or MATH 290-1 or MATH 291-1 or GEN_ENG 205-1 or GEN_ENG 206-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 360-1 MENU: Applied Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Linear ordinary differential equations, systems of linear ordinary differential equations, and applications. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 360-1 and any of MATH 250-0 , MATH 281-3 , GEN_ENG 205-4 , GEN_ENG 206-4 . MATH 226-0 or MATH 281-2 ; and MATH 290-3 or MATH 291-3 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 360-2 MENU: Applied Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Qualitative analysis of systems of ordinary differential equations. Linear partial differential equations. Fourier series and orthogonal functions. Applications. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 360-2 and any of MATH 381-0 , MATH 351-0 , or ES_APPM 311-2. MATH 360-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 365-0 Computational Methods in Mathematics (1 Unit)
description: An introduction to computational methods in mathematics. Students will apply computational techniques to analyze and interpret a variety of mathematical phenomena. MATH 230-2 or MATH 228-2 and MATH 240-0 , or MATH 290-3 , or MATH 291-3 .

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 366-0 Mathematical Models in Finance (1 Unit)
description: Cash flow computations. Basic financial concepts (stocks, bonds, options, arbitrage, hedging) and put-call parity. Binomial tree models. Risk-neutral valuation. Random walk and Brownian motion as a tool for modeling fluctuations. Options pricing. Applications of the central limit theorem. The Black-Scholes formula and partial differential equation. Numerical approximations. Some familiarity with differential equations is desirable. MATH 240-0 or MATH 281-3 or MATH 285-1 or MATH 290-1 or MATH 291-1 or GEN_ENG 205-1 or GEN_ENG 206-1 ; and MATH 310-1 or MATH 311-1 or MATH 314-0 or MATH 385-0 or STAT 320-1 or STAT 383-0 or IEMS 202-0 or ELEC_ENG 302-0 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 368-0 Introduction to Optimization (1 Unit)
description: Methods and concepts of optimization theory: linear programming, duality, convexity, and Kuhn-Tucker theory. MATH 226-0 or MATH 281-2 ; and MATH 291-3 , or MATH 300-0 and one of MATH 228-2 , MATH 230-2 , MATH 234-0 (former), MATH 281-2 , MATH 285-3 , MATH 290-3 , or ES_APPM 252-2 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 370-0 Mathematical Logic (1 Unit)
description: Mathematical formulation and rigorous discussion of logical systems, particularly the propositional calculus and the functional calculi of first and second order. Well-formed formulae, formal languages, proofs, tautologies, effective procedures, deduction theorems, axiom schemata. MATH 300-0 or MATH 291-3 or consent of the instructor. Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 381-0 Fourier Analysis and Boundary Value Problems for ISP (1 Unit)
description: Fourier series. Hilbert spaces and orthogonal functions. Parseval's theorem. Poisson summation formula and lattice points. Fourier integrals: Gaussian functions. Fourier inversion formula. Convolution. Sturm-Liouville theory. Applications to partial differential equations. Heat and wave equations. For ISP students only. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 381-0 and any of MATH 351-0 , MATH 360-2 , or ES_APPM 311-2. MATH 281-3 and PHYSICS 125-3 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 382-0 Complex Analysis for ISP (1 Unit)
description: Complex numbers. Analytic functions. Cauchy's theorem and the Cauchy integral formula. Series. Residues. For ISP students only. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 382-0 and either MATH 325-0 or ES_APPM 312-0 . MATH 281-3 and PHYSICS 125-3 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 385-0 Probability and Statistics for MMSS (1 Unit)
description: Probability theory and its applications in the social sciences. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 385-0 and any of MATH 310-1 , MATH 311-1 , MATH 314-0 , STAT 320-1 , STAT 383-0 , IEMS 202-0, or ELEC_ENG 302-0 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 386-1 Econometrics for MMSS (1 Unit)
description: Econometric methods. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 386-1 and ECON 381-1 . MATH 385-0 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 386-2 Econometrics for MMSS (1 Unit)
description: Econometric methods. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 386-2 and ECON 381-2 . MATH 386-1 . Formal Studies Distro Area

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 395-0 Undergraduate Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Topics in modern mathematics and relationships among different branches of mathematics. May be taken for only 1 unit of credit at a time but may be repeated for credit with change of topic. Advanced Expression

subject: MATH
title_units: MATH 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: Independent learning under the direction of a faculty adviser. Students must obtain departmental approval for a plan of study before enrolling in MATH 399-0 . © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 222-0 Thermodynamics & Statistical Mechanics - I (1 Unit)
description: Basic thermodynamics, applications to energy efficiency and climate change, and introduction to statistical thermodynamics. MATH 220-2 and GEN_ENG 205-3 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 224-0 Scientific and Embedded Programming in Python (1 Unit)
description: Python is arguably now the world's foremost programming language.  It is the go-to coding language for data scientists, machine learning researchers, design engineers, and anyone who needs to grab and process the vast amounts of data online, from networked sensors, or smart devices. Recently Python has become practical for coding in embedded systems, as well. Embedded microcontrollers are relevant for our annual robot design competition, NU engineering teams (Solar car, Baja), internships, and experimental apparatuses.  Our approach to coding emphasizes algorithm creation, debugging, methodical creation and partitioning in a modern notebook framework, as well as hardware-level access for microcontroller applications.  The course is taught in an active learning format. GEN_ENG 205-1 or GEN_ENG 206-1 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 233-0 Electronics Design (1 Unit)
description: Design and prototyping of analog and digital electronic circuits using semiconductor devices: diodes, transistors, op amps, logic chips, etc. Optical and other sensors, power electronics, filters, and feedback control. Extensive hands-on construction and debugging. Intended for engineers in all disciplines.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 240-0 Intro to Mechanical Design and Manufactrng (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to strategy and methods of designing, manufacturing, and testing of mechanical products. Material properties and selection methodology, engineering drawing and CAD, and simple manufacturing processes. MAT_SCI 201-0 ; CIV_ENV 216-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 241-0 Fluid Mechanics I (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of fluid mechanics. Properties and statics of fluids. Kinematics and dynamics of fluid motion-continuity, momentum, and energy equations. Dimensional analysis, flow in closed conduits. MATH 228-2 (may be taken concurrently) and GEN_ENG 205-4 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 301-0 Introduction to Robotics Laboratory (1 Unit)
description: A laboratory-based introduction to robotics. Focus will be on both hardware (sensors and actuators) and software (sensor processing and behavior development). Topics will include: the basics in kinematics, dynamics, control and motion planning; and an introduction to Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML). Cross-listed as COMP_SCI 301-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 314-0 Machine Dynamics (1 Unit)
description: This class covers the foundations of rigid multi-body mechanics. Topics include geometry of rigid bodies, rotating bodies, Lagrangian mechanics and variational principles, conservation of energy and momentum, symmetries, impact dynamics, and numerical methods that may be used to simulate mechanical systems. Students numerically simulate rigid body systems and use rigid body geometry to visualize simulations. GEN_ENG 205-4 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 315-0 Theory of Machines: Design of Elements (1 Unit)
description: Factors influencing the proportioning of machine elements-stresses, deformations, and failure criteria-as applied to shafts, springs, belts, bearings, gears. Lectures, laboratory. MECH_ENG 240-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 316-0 Mechanical Systems Design (1 Unit)
description: Design of mechanical systems such as cams, multi-bar linkages, and precision machines. Design principles and best practices. Case studies and team-based projects. MECH_ENG 315-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 320-0 Micro- and Nanomechanical Properties of Surfaces (1 Unit)
description: Micro and nanomechanical interactions between surfaces, fractal nature of surfaces, interfacial forces, principles of micromechanics, characterization of surfaces using atomic force microscopy, optical interferometry, and nanoindentation.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 322-0 Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics II (1 Unit)
description: Classical and statistical thermodynamics. MECH_ENG 222-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 327-0 Finite Elements for Stress Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Development of finite elements from variational principles and application to static stress analysis. Introduction to techniques for transient and generalized field problems. Computer implementation of finite element techniques. Taught with CIV_ENV 327-0 ; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 328-0 Computational Failure Analysis (1 Unit)
description: The course will cover the use of the scientific method for accident investigation, hypothesis development, and the use of the finite element method to analyze the root cause of a failure. Practical application problems for both civil and mechanical structures will be analyzed using commercial finite element codes (Abaqus, Hypermesh, LS-Dyna). CIV_ENV 327-0 or MECH_ENG 327-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 329-0 Mechanistic Data Science for Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Introduce mechanistic data science for engineering through the integration of mathematical scientific principles using six basic data science concepts: multimodal data generation and collection, extraction of mechanistic features, knowledge-driven dimension reduction, reduced order surrogate models, regression and classification models, and system and design. These concepts will be implemented using Python and MATLAB for engineering applications.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 333-0 Introduction to Mechatronics (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to microprocessor-controlled electromechanical systems. Interfacing sensors and actuators to computers, electrical and mechanical prototyping, dissection of a commercial product. Final team project. MECH_ENG 233-0 or ELEC_ENG 221-0 or BMD_ENG 308-0 , or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 340-1 Computer Integrated Manufacturing: Manufacturing Processes (1 Unit)
description: Use of computers to improve productivity and reduce costs in the manufacture of discrete parts and assemblies. Manufacturing processes: Analysis and evaluation of process usage in the contemporary manufacturing environment. MECH_ENG 240-0 or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 340-2 Computer Integrated Manufacturing: CAD/CAM (1 Unit)
description: Use of computers to improve productivity and reduce costs in the manufacture of discrete parts and assemblies. CAD/ CAM: Geometric modeling, dimensioning systems, tolerances, design for manufacture, programming of machine tools. MECH_ENG 340-1 or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 340-3 Computer Integrated Manufacturing: Automation (1 Unit)
description: Use of computers to improve productivity and reduce costs in the manufacture of discrete parts and assemblies. Manufacturing automation: sensors, actuators, and computers for automation; principles of computer control; programmable logic controllers; robotic devices; assembly automation. MECH_ENG 340-2 or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 341-0 Computational Methods for Engineering Design (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to a wide range of computational techniques for engineering design. Modeling, simulation, optimization, design software, examples, and projects with emphasis on computational techniques for design and manufacturing related applications.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 346-0 Introduction to Tribology (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of surface contact: surface topography, asperity contact, interfacial phenomena. Friction theories and wear mechanisms. Temperatures in sliding contacts. Hydrodynamic, hydrostatic, elastohydrodynamic, and boundary lubrication.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 359-0 Reliability Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Probability concepts and random variables. Failure rates and reliability testing. Wearin, wear-out, random failures. Probabilistic treatment of loads, capacity, safety factors. Reliability of redundant and maintained systems. Fault tree analysis. GEN_ENG 205-4 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 360-0 Mechanics of Sports (1 Unit)
description: Applications of mechanics and mathematical modeling to sports, including baseball, basketball, golf, soccer, swimming, and running, among others. Introduction to the biomechanics of sports.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 362-0 Stress Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Theory of elasticity: elastic stability, principle of minimum potential energy, Rayleigh-Ritz methods. Introduction to finite element methods of stress analysis: computer implementation and use of commercial codes. Structural analysis of rods, beams, columns, and plates. CIV_ENV 216-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 363-0 Mechanical Vibrations (1 Unit)
description: Analysis of vibrations in single and multi-degree of freedom systems. Free and forced vibrations with various types of damping. Response to steady-state and transient excitations. MECH_ENG 314-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 364-0 Introduction to Aerospace Engineering (1 Unit)
description: The purpose of the course is to learn the language of aerospace engineering and to explore emerging concepts in this field. This course will cover essential topics in areas relevant to aerospace engineering including Aerodynamics, Flight Dynamics, Propulsion, and Orbital Mechanics. Computational tools for structural analysis, fluid flow calculations, and flight dynamics modeling will be introduced. CIV_ENV 216-0 , MECH_ENG 241-0 or equivalent.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 366-0 Finite Elements for Design & Optimizatn (1 Unit)
description: Numerical methods for interaction and optimal CAD. Fully stressed design; design sensitivity analysis and descent methods; optimality criteria to automated design. MECH_ENG 327-0 or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 367-0 Quantitative Methods in Life Cycle Analysis (1 Unit)
description: Lifecycle analysis (LCA) framework for environmental assessment of technology systems, focusing on modeling methods for systems mass and energy flows, process and input-output-based systems inventories, environmental impact analysis, and methods for robust engineering decisions. MECH_ENG 367-0 is taught with CHEM_ENG 367-0 ; may not receive credit for both courses.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 371-0 Combustion Engines (1 Unit)
description: Theoretical and actual cycles, combustion, detonation, carburetion, fuels, performance characteristics, and fuel-cell power.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 373-0 Engineering Fluid Mechanics (1 Unit)
description: Laminar and turbulent duct flows. Boundary layers and potential flows. Lift and drag forces. Thermodynamics and mechanics of compressible flow. Nozzle flows and choking. Wave motion and shock waves. Applications to fluid machinery. MECH_ENG 241-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 377-0 Heat Transfer (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation. Steady and transient heat conduction in solids. Forced and free convection in fluids. Properties of thermal radiation. Radiation heat transfer between solids. Solar radiation. MECH_ENG 241-0 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 378-0 Applied Computational Fluid Dynamics and Heat Transfer (1 Unit)
description: This course provides an understanding of the theory and process of computational flow analysis by giving students the opportunity to use commercial simulation software (ANSYS/Fluent) to solve fluid flow problems. Topics covered include conservation of mass, momentum and energy; boundary conditions; turbulence modeling; mesh generation; solution procedures; and verification/validation. Topics will be presented through lectures, hands-on computer lab sessions, and team-based projects.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 380-0 Thermal Energy Systems Design (1 Unit)
description: Applications of the principles of energy engineering analysis to the design of thermal systems. Consideration of such systems as air conditioning, oil piping, refrigeration, fluid distribution, and pneumatic control. Projects will be tailored to the class. Solution of open-ended design problems including introduction to EES (Engineering Equation Solver) software that has built-in thermophysical properties.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 381-0 Introduction to Micro-electro-mechanical Systems (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to MEMS devices, with an emphasis on their manufacturing and mechanical behavior. Materials properties, microfabrication technology, mechanical behavior of microstructures, design, and packaging. Case studies on sensors, wireless communications, fluidic systems, microengines, and biological devices. CIV_ENV 216-0 or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 382-0 Experiments in Micro- and Nano Science and Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Interdisciplinary topics spanning the physical and biological sciences and engineering. Seven integrated labs in which students acquire hands-on experience in various aspects of micro-and nanoscience and engineering: cleanroom microfabrication, flow visualization in micro-channels, nanomechanics, AFM and dippen nanolithography, multiphysics computational tools, and experimental techniques to evaluate micro-and nanoscale devices. MECH_ENG 381-0 or consent of instructor.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 390-0 Intro to Dynamic Systems (1 Unit)
description: Modeling the dynamic behavior of physical systems. Concepts of causality, dependent and independent storages, and state. Introduction to bond graphs. Generation of state equations; analytical and computer simulation of system behavior. Application to problems of engineering interest. MECH_ENG 241-0 ; CIV_ENV 216-0 ; GEN_ENG 205-4 .

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 395-0 Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the department.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 398-1 Engineering Design I (1 Unit)
description: Experience in the creative process of design. Defining product specifications, developing and analyzing ideas, using CAD drawings, building physical prototypes, demonstrating feasibility, and achieving full alpha-level functionality.

subject: MECH_ENG
title_units: MECH_ENG 398-2 Engineering Design II (1 Unit)
description: Experience in the creative process of design. Defining product specifications, developing and analyzing ideas, using CAD drawings, building physical prototypes, demonstrating feasibility, and achieving full alpha-level functionality. MECH_ENG 399-0 Projects (1-3 Units) Special studies to be done under faculty direction. subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 101-7 College Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and introducing skills necessary to thriving at Northwestern. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 101-8 First-Year Writing Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Small, writing and discussion-oriented course exploring a specific topic or theme, and focused on the fundamentals of effective, college-level written communication. Not eligible to be applied towards a WCAS major or minor except where specifically indicated.

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 200-0 Making the Modern Middle East: Culture, Politics, History (1 Unit)
description: The emergence of the Middle East as a world region and its representation in art, literature, and film in relation to geopolitics from the colonial period to the present. Global Perspectives on Power, Justice, and Equity Historical Studies Distro Area

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 290-3 Introductory Topics in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within the social and behavioral sciences. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 290-4 Introductory Topics in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within historical studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 290-5 Introductory Topics in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within ethics and values areas of study. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Ethical and Evaluative Thinking Foundational Disci Ethics  Values Distro Area

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 290-6 Introductory Topics in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within literature and fine arts areas of study. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 301-1 Seminar in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to the study of the Middle East and North Africa. Content varies with annual theme. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic. Courses need not be taken in sequence.

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 301-2 Seminar in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to the study of the Middle East and North Africa. Content varies with annual theme. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic. Courses need not be taken in sequence.

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 301-3 Seminar in Middle East and North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to the study of the Middle East and North Africa. Content varies with annual theme. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic. Courses need not be taken in sequence.

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 390-3 Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within the social and behavioral sciences. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area Social and Behavioral Science Foundational Discipl

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 390-4 Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within historical studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Historical Studies Distro Area Historical Studies Foundational Discipline

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 390-5 Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within ethics and values areas of study. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Ethical and Evaluative Thinking Foundational Disci Ethics  Values Distro Area

subject: MENA
title_units: MENA 390-6 Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies (1 Unit)
description: Content and prerequisites vary; within literature and fine arts areas of study. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area Literature and Arts Foundational Discipline

title_units: MENA 399-0 Independent Study (1 Unit)
description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced undergraduates. © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 211-1 Social Science Theories & Meth-First Yr (1 Unit)
description: A fast-paced mathematical treatment of intermediate microeconomics designed for mathematically sophisticated students.  No previous training in microeconomics is assumed.  Topics covered include consumer and producer behavior in market economies, equilibrium in competitive and monopolistic markets, public goods and externalities, and welfare analysis. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 211-2 Social Science Theories & Meth-First Yr (1 Unit)
description: Game theory.

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 211-3 Social Science Theories & Meth-First Yr (1 Unit)
description: Formal models in social science disciplines other than economics. Social  Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 300-0 Foundations of Mathematical Social Science (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to the core mathematical elements of formal Social Science, including Individual Decision Making, Choice Under Uncertainty, Social Choice and Welfare, Efficiency Concepts, and Dynamic Decision-Making.

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 311-1 Social Science Theories & Meth-2nd Yr (1 Unit)
description: Advanced game theory.

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 311-2 Social Science Theories & Meth-2nd Yr (1 Unit)
description: Advanced formal models in social science disciplines other than economics.

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 398-1 Senior Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Senior thesis seminar. Advanced Expression

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 398-2 Senior Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Senior thesis seminar. Advanced Expression

subject: MMSS
title_units: MMSS 398-3 Senior Seminar (1 Unit)
description: Senior thesis seminar. subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 112-0 Applied Composition for Music Majors (1 Unit)
description: Original composition; individual instruction.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 211-0 Class Composition (1 Unit)
description: Class instruction in techniques of composition. Open to music and non-music majors.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 212-0 Applied Composition for Music Majors (1 Unit)
description: Original composition; individual instruction.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 305-0 Optional Recital (0 Unit)

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 312-0 Applied Composition for Music Majors (1 Unit)
description: Original composition; individual instruction.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 314-1 Instrumentation (1 Unit)
description: Instruments of the orchestra; scoring techniques; analysis of instrumental combinations. MUSIC 211-3 or consent of instructor.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 314-2 Orchestration (1 Unit)
description: Stylistic scoring projects; analysis of orchestral and chamber scores. MUS_COMP 314-1 or consent of instructor.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 314-3 Advanced Orchestration (1 Unit)
description: Contemporary scoring techniques; creative projects; analysis of orchestral and chamber scores. MUS_COMP 314-2 , graduate standing, or consent of instructor.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 335-0 Selected Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. Writing projects; analysis of scores; contemporary stylistic techniques, performers, composers, and materials; in-class performances of original work. May be repeated for credit.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 336-0 Contemporary Repertoire (1 Unit)

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 337-0 Topics in Contemporary Repertoire (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary by quarter. Close study of specific recent compositional styles, which may include minimalism, complexity, music of the last decade, experimental music.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 338-0 Composer Portraits (1 Unit)
description: Composers vary by quarter. Portrait studies of the work of a major composer or composers, e.g., Ferneyhough; Lutoslawski; Cage; Birtwistle and Maxwell Davies.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 339-0 Compositional Concepts and Techniques (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary by quarter. Content, musical spaces, extended techniques, and spectralism.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 340-0 Composition Workshop (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary by quarter. Examples include Composer/Performer, Composing for Percussion, Composing for Dance, Composing for Solo Instrument.

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 370-0 Junior Recital (0 Unit)

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 380-0 Senior Recital (0 Unit)

subject: MUS_COMP
title_units: MUS_COMP 390-0 Composition Colloquium (0 Unit)
description: Discussion of contemporary compositional techniques. subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 300-0 Introduction to Music Technology (1 Unit)
description: Introduction of key concepts in acoustics, digital audio theory, production, and postproduction. Through projects and presentations, students will learn to record and edit their work, use notation software, communicate with recording engineers, and prepare and present work online.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 321-0 Producing in the Virtual Studio (1 Unit)
description: Techniques for creating and producing music in the context of a computer-based audio production environment. Topics include MIDI, audio editing, plugins, effects processing, mastering, and basic surround mixing. Assignments include creative projects. MUS_TECH 300-0 or equivalent experience and consent of instructor.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 322-0 Recording Techniques (1 Unit)
description: Microphone and placement techniques including stereo and close/distant miking of voices, acoustic instruments, and ensembles. Console design, signal flow, and dynamics processing. Projects include recording assignments. MUS_TECH 300-0 or equivalent experience and consent of instructor.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 335-0 Selected Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated with change of topic.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 340-0 Composing With Computers (1 Unit)
description: Foundational techniques of composition using music and audio software. Techniques of algorithmic composition, sound processing. Analysis of electroacoustic music. Assignments include student compositions. MUS_TECH 300-0 or equivalent experience.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 345-0 Technology-Based Performance (1 Unit)
description: Creation, rehearsal, and performance of technology-based music in a group setting. Topics include real-time interaction, technological performance interfaces, application of algorithmic methods.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 350-0 Studio Techniques for Electroacoustic Music (1 Unit)
description: Advanced projects in electroacoustic composition, audio programming (Max/MSP), audio engineering, or electronic instrument design; includes a largescale project, typically developed from the student's previous music technology course work. MUS_TECH 340-0 , MUS_TECH 345-0 , or equivalent experience.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 355-2 History and Analysis of Electroacoustic Music (1 Unit)
description: Survey of electronic music repertoire from 1948 through the end of the analog era and the introduction of digital music. Examination of the aesthetic motivations and technical approaches that have shaped electroacoustic music throughout its history, focusing on the interaction between technical innovation and creativity.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 365-0 Electronic Film Music (1 Unit)
description: The course will focus on electronic approaches to film scoring. It will consist of historical overview (going back to the 1940s), significant composers and repertoire examples, and practical exercises in scoring.  The course will cover multiple film genres with special emphasis on science fiction, horror, and fantasy. Composers covered include John Carpenter, Vangelis, Jerry Goldsmith, Dave Porter, Hans Zimmer, and Hildur Guðnadóttir.

subject: MUS_TECH
title_units: MUS_TECH 385-0 Senior Project (1 Unit)
description: Independent project in music technology. subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 251-0 Intro to Music Cognition (1 Unit)
description: An introduction to music cognition for music undergraduates as well as students with limited music backgrounds. Readings primarily from secondary sources, with some primary sources as well.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 313-0 Analytical Approaches to World Musics (1 Unit)
description: This class explores aspects of musical rhythm, meter, pitch, harmony, and structure through a comparative lens. It is centered around transcription, beginning with theories of the role of transcription for the researcher, and uses active listening as a way of cultivating an awareness of musical behavior of some of the many musics of the world.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 316-0 16th Century Counterpoint (1 Unit)
description: Contrapuntal textures from two to four voices. Cadence and form, melodic line and motive, rhythm, simple and complex imitation, and treatment of dissonance in the sacred music of Lassus, Josquin, and Palestrina.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 317-0 Historical Improvisation (1 Unit)
description: The study of harmony at the keyboard as learned by musicians since the early 17th century. Figured bass is an essential subject for performers of early music (including Bach and Mozart) and a key to the analysis of most pre-20th century European music.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 318-0 18th Century Counterpoint (1 Unit)
description: Baroque dance suite, chorale prelude, invention, fugue, chiefly involving the music of J. S. Bach. Melodic, harmonic, structural characteristics; contrapuntal techniques.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 321-0 Classical Form (1 Unit)
description: An examination of phrase-construction and punctuation in the musical forms of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. The focus will typically be on Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven's skillful use of conventional formal structures to engage creatively with listeners' expectations.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 322-1 Rhythm and Meter I (1 Unit)
description: Close reading and discussion of key canonical texts from the last three decades' rich scholarship in rhythm and meter as well as innovative new work. Each student completes a substantial analytical and/or theoretical paper.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 322-2 Rhythm and Meter II (1 Unit)
description: Among the most remarkable developments in the music theory of recent decades have been the rapid advances in the study of rhythm and meter. This course combines close readings of canonical texts and innovative work in this field with analysis of rhythm and meter in common-practice repertoire.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 325-0 Style and Phrase (1 Unit)
description: An investigation of the musical phrase in the long 18th century (1680–1830) from the perspective of schema theory. A schema is a typically short, memorable pattern defined by a characteristic pairing of scale degree progressions in the melody and bass, and an accompanying harmonic progression. Such schemata are the essential building blocks of composition in the long 18th century.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 331-0 Analytical Studies (1 Unit)
description: Extension and refinement of concepts and techniques acquired in first and second year music theory.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 333-0 Analysis of Popular Music (1 Unit)
description: Course objectives are (1) developing skill in analyzing popular music and (2) exploring how music scholars have studied traits such as form, harmony, timbre, etc. in a variety of popular repertoires. Students will become familiar with recurring issues in the interpretation of popular music and develop the ability to form their own critical interpretations using music analysis as a tool.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 335-0 Selected Topics in Music Theory (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 336-0 Selected Topics in Music Cognition (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 340-0 Analysis of Recorded Performance (1 Unit)
description: This class provides an overview of the recent literature in music theory and cognition, focusing on articles published in the main journals of these fields. Students will engage with the current themes in the literature, while also situating these readings within a broader historical context in the field.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 341-0 Sound to Structure (1 Unit)
description: Music theory privileges the parameters of pitch (as melody, harmony, and counterpoint) and rhythm (as surface rhythm and meter), but music as experienced is much more than the sum of these. This class engages how musical experience arises from and is shaped by other parameters, notably timbre, register, texture, and dynamics, across musical styles and periods.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 345-0 Experimental and Empirical Methods in Music Theory (1 Unit)
description: Empirical methods in music research have been used to study aspects of musical style, performance practice, authorship, musical behaviors and auditory perception, among other topics. This course provides a foundation and overview of empirical methods used in musicological and music-theoretic research, and equips students with the tools needed to critically engage with the literature in the field while designing their own empirically-based music research.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 348-0 Corpus Studies (1 Unit)
description: Corpus studies, or distant readings of multiple musical works, are often employed as a way of better understanding issues such as the relationships between pieces, authorship, trends over time, or differences and similarities between genres. In this class, we will explore the techniques, history, and philosophy of such approaches, and will construct and analyze our own corpora. For the most part, this class will deal with notated scores, and students will be encouraged to ask their own research questions of the music that they are most interested in.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 355-0 Analysis of Post-Tonal Music (1 Unit)
description: Techniques for analysis of atonal and nonfunctional tonal music, including serial, set-theoretic, and parametric approaches. Emphasis on music of Schoenberg, Webern, Berg, Stravinsky, and Debussy. Selected readings in analytic literature. MUSIC 211-3 or equivalent.

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 385-0 Senior Project (1 Unit)

subject: MUS_THRY
title_units: MUS_THRY 390-0 Music Theory Colloquium (0 Unit)
description: Special topics presentations for music theory students. subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 111-1 Music Theory  I (0.5 Unit)
description: Music as sound in time. Analytical studies in forms, media, textures, and harmonic and melodic materials.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 111-2 Music Theory II (0.5 Unit)
description: Music as sound in time. Analytical studies in forms, media, textures, and harmonic and melodic materials. MUSIC 111-1 .

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 111-3 Music Theory III (0.5 Unit)
description: Music as sound in time. Analytical studies in forms, media, textures, and harmonic and melodic materials. MUSIC 111-2 .

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 126-1 Aural Skills I (0.5 Unit)
description: Sight-singing and ear-training; drill in recognition of melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic patterns and aural analysis through listening and dictation. Progresses through six levels of proficiency.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 126-2 Aural Skills II (0.5 Unit)
description: Sight-singing and ear-training; drill in recognition of melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic patterns and aural analysis through listening and dictation. Progresses through six levels of proficiency.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 126-3 Aural Skills III (0.5 Unit)
description: Sight-singing and ear-training; drill in recognition of melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic patterns and aural analysis through listening and dictation. Progresses through six levels of proficiency.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 127-1 Keyboard Skills 1 (0.5 Unit)
description: This is the first quarter of a year-long sequence. This track is for beginning piano students. Topics include repertoire, a healthful approach to piano technique, scales, keyboard harmony, ensemble, sight reading, and creative work.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 127-2 Keyboard Skills 2 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 127-3 Keyboard Skills 3 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 128-1 Keyboard Skills 1+ (0.5 Unit)
description: This is the first quarter of a year-long sequence. This track is for students with a little piano background, typically 1-2 years of previous study. Topics include repertoire, technique, scales, and keyboard harmony. Ensemble, sight reading, and creative work are covered as well.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 128-2 Keyboard Skills 2+ (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 128-3 Keyboard Skills 3+ (0.5 Unit)
description: Keyboard Skills 3+.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 129-1 Keyboard Skills 1-2-3 (0.5 Unit)
description: This course is for students with piano background. Topics include sight reading, keyboard theory, harmonizing melodies, solo repertoire, and ensemble.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 129-2 Keyboard Skills 4-5-6 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 130-1 Keyboard Skills for Piano Majors (0.5 Unit)
description: This is the first quarter of a year-long sequence. Topics include vocal and string quartet score reading, keyboard theory, sight reading including 18th century examples, with corresponding harmonic language, rhythmic, and idiomatic patterns. Other topics include harmonizing melodies, creative work, and ensemble.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 130-2 Keyboard Skills for Piano Majors (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 130-3 Keyboard Skills for Piano Majors (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 211-1 Music Theory IV (0.5 Unit)
description: Music as sound in time. Analytical studies in forms, media, textures, and harmonic and melodic materials. MUSIC 111-3 or consent of instructor.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 211-2 Music Theory V (0.5 Unit)
description: Music as sound in time. Analytical studies in forms, media, textures, and harmonic and melodic materials. MUSIC 211-1 .

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 211-3 Music Theory VI (0.5 Unit)
description: Music as sound in time. Analytical studies in forms, media, textures, and harmonic and melodic materials. MUSIC 211-2 .

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 214-0 The Classical Canon (1 Unit)
description: This course explores the idea of "classical music," a canon of works united not by scoring, age, nationality, or style, but rather by the perception of timeless value. What musical and social factors influenced inclusion or exclusion? This course seeks to both introduce a variety of extremely famous "classical" works and to interrogate the processes that made them famous.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 215-0 Performers and Performance (1 Unit)
description: This course focuses on what it means or meant to be a musician in different places and times. Students will gain introductory literacy in diverse modes of musical performance and learn to conceive of music history through the lens of performance rather than through composers and works, including reflection on how to locate themselves within a complex global music scene.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 216-0 Music in the Present (1 Unit)
description: This course explores contemporary musical practices through their circulation, reception, and mediation. Examples are drawn from Western art, popular, and global musical genres though we will explore how all these musics share-at least in part-a similar mode of distribution in the early twenty-first century. Emphasis is placed on technology, listening practices, aesthetics, and contemporary musical institutions.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 226-1 Aural Skills IV (0.5 Unit)
description: Sight-singing and ear-training; drill in recognition of melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic patterns and aural analysis through listening and dictation. Progresses through six levels of proficiency.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 226-2 Aural Skills V (0.5 Unit)
description: Sight-singing and ear-training; drill in recognition of melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic patterns and aural analysis through listening and dictation. Progresses through six levels of proficiency.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 226-3 Aural Skills VI (0.5 Unit)
description: Sight-singing and ear-training; drill in recognition of melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic patterns and aural analysis through listening and dictation. Progresses through six levels of proficiency.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 227-1 Keyboard Skills 4 (0.5 Unit)
description: This is the first quarter of a second, year-long sequence required but not limited to Music Ed majors. Students who were placed in both Level 1 and the Level 1+ tracks will take this course. Topics include repertoire, technique, harmonizing melodies, sight reading, score reading, ensemble and creative work.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 227-2 Keyboard Skills 5 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 227-3 Keyboard Skills 6 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 298-0 Student Organized Seminar (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 310-0 Biological Foundations of Speech and Music (1 Unit)
description: Anatomy and physiology of the central auditory pathway, experience-related neural plasticity, right/left brain specialization, audiovisual integration, auditory learning and perception, and neural encoding of speech and music.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 320-0 Listening in the Age of the Algorithm (1 Unit)
description: Whether it’s the movies we watch, the flights we buy, the goods we buy, or the music we listen to, algorithmic recommendation is changing how we experience the world around us. This class explores what it means to listen to music in an age of computational curation. As these systems are meant to model human preference, we will study what it means to have musical preferences, perceived musical features as similar, and what the role of social interactions on our own listening behaviors. No programming or musical experience is necessary, but we will be working with examples in both basic musical notation and code.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 327-1 Keyboard Skills 7 (0.5 Unit)
description: This is the first quarter of a year-long sequence required but not restricted to Choral Music Ed majors. Topics include vocal scores, sight reading, solo piano repertoire, and technique.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 327-2 Keyboard Skills 8 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 327-3 Keyboard Skills 9 (0.5 Unit)
description: Class instruction in keyboard skills.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 330-0 Materials, Performance, Practice & Pedagogy (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 335-0 Selected Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 350-0 Alexander Technique (0.5 Unit)
description: Methods of using the body efficiently to reduce unnecessary tension and stress in instrumental and vocal performance.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 360-0 Career Innovation in Music and the Performing Arts (1 Unit)
description: Models of performing arts careers; innovative approaches to existing career paths. Case studies, guest speakers. Topics include fee and contract negotiation, artist and booking management, fundraising and grant writing, marketing and public relations, social media, and organizational and business structures. Open to music majors only.

subject: MUSIC
title_units: MUSIC 397-0 Summer Internship (0 Unit)
description: Field experience as an intern. MUSIC 398-0 Internship (0.5-4 Units) Field experience as an intern. Requirements include journal and final paper. subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 230-0 Woodwind Class (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 231-0 Guitar Class (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 234-0 Double Reeds Class (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 235-0 High Brass Class (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 236-0 Low Brass Class (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 237-0 String Class I (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 238-0 String Class II (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 239-0 Percussion Class (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 240-0 Classroom Instruments (0.5 Unit)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 260-0 Introduction to Music Education (1 Unit)
description: This course is designed as an introduction to the field of music education. It will provide an overview of the multifaceted nature of K-12 music teaching and learning and serve as a foundation for the construction of your own beliefs and practices as a teacher. We will observe music classrooms as well as read about and discuss a variety of current issues and exciting movements in music education.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 314-0 Practicum (0 Unit)
description: Practicum lab linked to MUSIC_ED 361-0 , MUSIC_ED 362-0 , MUSIC_ED 364-0 , MUSIC_ED 365-0 , MUSIC_ED 366-0 , and MUSIC_ED 367-0 .

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 326-0 World Music Pedagogy (1 Unit)
description: This course is designed to explore the history, philosophy, and practical implementation of world music in music education settings. Develops in students a deeper understanding of the value of world music experiences in music education contexts and the ability to develop and implement world music activities in a variety of classroom settings.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 327-0 Teaching Exceptional Children (1 Unit)
description: Topics will include U.S. legislation relating to the education of individuals with disabilities, specific disabilities and their impact on student behavior and learning (behavioral disorders, cognitive, speech, and language disorders, autism spectrum disorders, hearing and visual impairments, physical disabilities, person-first language), Universal Design for Learning, and accommodations, adaptations, and differentiation for the music classroom. Students may engage virtually in weekly community field service at a local school for children with disabilities.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 335-0 Selected Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 345-0 Music in the Interdisciplinary Curriculum (1 Unit)
description: Promoting music and arts-based interdisciplinary experiences for elementary and secondary school students. Curriculum developing interrelating arts disciplines (such as music, art, and literature) and connecting the arts with non-arts disciplines (such as history and social studies).

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 358-0 Philosophy of Music Education (1 Unit)
description: The purpose of this course is to stimulate your thinking about your role as a music educator, and the role of music in the broader educative experience. Exploration of philosophical principles, concepts, and ideas that provide music education with purpose and direction. This class will help you articulate a vision for music in schools and a philosophical orientation toward music teaching and learning.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 361-0 Teaching General Music I (1 Unit)
description: For grades K-5, curriculum materials and strategies for developing musical growth. Laboratory experiences; developing creativity in the music classroom. Open only to music majors or with consent of instructor. MUSIC_ED 240-0 .

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 362-0 Teaching General Music II (1 Unit)
description: For grades 6-12, effective teaching of general music classes in middle and high school. Available curriculum materials; innovative approaches. MUSIC_ED 231-0 .

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 363-0 Teaching High School Nonperformance Courses (1 Unit)
description: Planning and teaching high school music, arts, humanities courses. Present practices; development of exemplary course plans.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 364-0 Teaching Instrumental Music I (1 Unit)
description: Teaching and administrative principles for elementary and middle school instrumental music programs. Rehearsal dynamics, conducting, rehearsal room management, and pedagogy for school ensembles.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 365-0 Teaching Instrumental Music II (1 Unit)
description: Teaching and administrative principles for secondary school instrumental music programs. Rehearsal dynamics, conducting, rehearsal room management, and pedagogy for school ensembles. MUSIC_ED 364-0 .

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 366-0 Teaching Choral Music I (1 Unit)
description: Development and application of skills, knowledge, and understandings for teaching choral music in elementary and middle school.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 367-0 Teaching Choral Music II (1 Unit)
description: Continuation of MUSIC_ED 366-0 . High school choral program, curriculum model, repertoire, sight-reading, rehearsal techniques, programming, administration.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 368-0 Teaching Composition in the Schools (1 Unit)
description: The purpose of this course is to study practical concepts and theories of teaching composition and improvisation in K-12 schools, learn about the design of curricular materials for teaching composition and improvisation, and compose and improvise using a variety of approaches and mediums that are applicable to general, choral, and instrumental music classrooms.

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 369-0 Research and Evaluation in Music Education (1 Unit)
description: Procedures and issues in research and evaluation in music teaching. Practical application of research to decision making. MUSIC_ED 370-0 Student Teaching in the Elementary School: General Music (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 371-0 Student Teaching in the Middle School/Junior High School: General/Choral (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 373-0 Student Teaching in the Senior High School: Choral and Nonperformance (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 375-0 Student Teaching in the Elementary School: Instrumental (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 376-0 Student Teaching in the Middle School/Junior High School: Instrumental (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 377-0 Student Teaching in the Senior High School: Instrumental and Nonperformance (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 380-0 Student Teaching in the Elementary School: General Music (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 381-0 Student Teaching in the Middle School/Junior High School: General/Choral (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 383-0 Student Teaching in the Senior High School: Choral and Nonperformance (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 385-0 Student Teaching in the Elementary School: Instrumental (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 386-0 Student Teaching in the Middle School/Junior High School: Instrumental (1-4 Units) MUSIC_ED 387-0 Student Teaching in the Senior High School: Instrumental and Nonperformance (1-4 Units)

subject: MUSIC_ED
title_units: MUSIC_ED 390-0 Student Teaching Colloquium (0 Unit)

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 313-0 World Music Cultures (1 Unit)
description: Introduction to both the world's musical variety and common issues related to music cultures worldwide.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 323-0 Topics in Ethnomusicology (1 Unit)
description: Ethnomusicology history, bibliographical resources, methods, and theories. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 326-0 Topics in World Music: Asia (1 Unit)
description: The musical traditions of South Asia, East Asia, and Southeast Asia. Topics include characteristics of instruments and instrumental ensembles, sound structures, theatrical traditions, and vocal performance.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 329-0 Topics in Middle Eastern Music (1 Unit)
description: History, basic tenets, and aesthetic of Islam; the musics of Islamic cultures from North Africa, Spain, the Middle East, central Asia, and the Indian subcontinent. Methods of contextualizing musical cultures and critical methodology related to gender, postcolonial theory, and religion. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 330-0 Russian Fairy Tale Opera (1 Unit)
description: Russian cultural and national identity studied through folk tales and their musical counterparts in Russian opera. Current critical theory, the portrayal of women, the interplay of nationalism and gender, and the East-West dichotomy. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 331-0 Orientalism and Music (1 Unit)
description: The imagery of the East in the music of the West expressed in musical genres of various historical periods; focus on romantic opera and contemporary musical culture. Orientalism as formulated by Edward Said, developed by John MacKenzie, and clarified through references in literature and the visual arts. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 332-0 Music and Gypsies (1 Unit)
description: Romany music from Hungary, Spain, the Balkans, Turkey, the Middle East, and India; Andalucian flamenco; 19thcentury opera and operetta (Bizet's Carmen , Verdi's La Traviata ); instrumental works by Haydn, Liszt, Brahms, and others; and more recent "world" music phenomena.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 333-0 Topics in Popular Music (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 334-0 Russian Modernism (1 Unit)
description: Russian music after Tchaikovsky, notably Scriabin, Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Prokofiev, and Shostakovich.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 335-0 Selected Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 335-SA Selected Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 338-0 Expressionism (1 Unit)
description: The interaction of music (Schoenberg, Berg, Webern, Weill, Hindemith, et al.) with painting (Kandinsky et al.), poetry (Stefan George et al.), theater (Wedekind, Brecht, et al.), and dance (Kurt Jooss et al.) in early-20thcentury Germany and Austria.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 339-0 Music and Gender (1 Unit)
description: The many intersections between music and ideas of gender; focus on composition, characterization, patronage, and performance. Elite and popular Western musical forms from the Middle Ages to 2000 in relation to gender issues in other cultures' musics. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 341-0 Music and the Visual Arts (1 Unit)
description: The many ways in which the senses of sight and hearing interact in Western images of music and music making as well as in select musical works inspired by concurrent ideas or movements in the visual arts.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 342-0 Authenticity (1 Unit)
description: Authenticity in music at the turn of the 21st century, focusing on three music genres most closely associated with that idea's cultural and philosophical considerations: early music, country music, and world or ethnic music. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 343-0 Music and Shakespeare (1 Unit)
description: An exploration of some of the many intersections between Shakespearean drama and music from the late 16th through early 21st centuries, including study of plays, opera, ballet, film, musical theater, art song, popular music, and the symphony.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 344-0 Music and Film (1 Unit)
description: Theory and practice of music as a part of the processes of making and viewing films, from the beginning of the sound era to the present. Topic varies but typically focuses on a specific film genre's musical traditions, techniques, personalities, and problems.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 345-0 From Literature to Opera to Film (1 Unit)
description: Selected operas, based on literary or theatrical works, that in turn inspired films. Examination of the literary or theatrical inspiration, the opera as written for stage, and film and video adaptations.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 346-0 Composer Topics (1 Unit)
description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 347-0 The Lied (1 Unit)
description: Survey of voice-piano settings of German poems, from Mozart through Richard Strauss.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 348-0 Bel Canto Opera (1 Unit)
description: Italian opera in the early-to- mid-19th century. The relations of Rossini, Donizetti, and Bellini to the operatic culture of their time.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 350-0 Topics in Medieval Music (1 Unit)
description: Gregorian and medieval chant, secular monophony, and the development of polyphony from the earliest records through the music of Ockeghem and Busnois. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 351-0 Topics in 16th Century Music (1 Unit)
description: Middle and late renaissance and early manifestations of the baroque, from Josquin through the Gabrielis. Literature  Fine Arts Distro Area

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 352-0 Topics in 17th Century Music (1 Unit)
description: The baroque from Monteverdi through Bach and Handel.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 353-0 Topics in 18th Century Music (1 Unit)
description: Representative works and critical studies of European art music from the Arcadian reform of opera through the Napoleonic era.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 354-0 Topics in 19th Century Music (1 Unit)
description: Representative works and critical studies of European art music from the Congress of Vienna to the death of Mahler.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 355-0 Topics in 20th Century Music (1 Unit)
description: Representative works and critical studies of art music from Debussy to the late 20th century.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 356-0 Topics in Contemporary Music (1 Unit)
description: Representative works and critical studies of art music from 2000 to the present.

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 385-0 Senior Project (1 Unit)

subject: MUSICOL
title_units: MUSICOL 390-0 Musicology Colloquium (0 Unit)
description: MUSICOL 399-0 Independent Study (0.5-1 Unit) © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page. subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 110-0 Introduction to Naval Organization (0 Unit)
description: This course is a general introduction to the USN and USMC that emphasizes organizational structure, warfare components and assigned roles/missions of USN/USMC. It covers all aspects of Naval Service from its relative position within the DoD to the specific warfare communities/career paths and includes basic elements of leadership and USN and USMC Core Values.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 120-0 Sea Power and Maritime Affairs (1 Unit)
description: This course is a study of the U.S. Navy and the influence of sea power on history that incorporates both a historical and political science process to explore the major events, attitudes, personalities, and circumstances that have imbued the U.S. Navy with its proud history and rich tradition.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 210-0 Marine Navigation (1 Unit)
description: This course is an in-depth study of the theory, principles, procedures, and application of plotting, piloting, and electronic navigation, as well as an introduction to maneuvering boards. Students learn piloting techniques, the use of charts, the use of visual and electronic aids, and the theory of operation of both magnetic and gyrocompasses. Students develop practical skills in plotting and electronic navigation.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 220-0 Naval Ship Systems II - Naval Weapons (1 Unit)
description: This course outlines the theory and employment of weapons systems. Students explore the processes of detection, evaluation, threat analysis, weapon selection, delivery, guidance, and explosives. Fire control systems and major weapons types are discussed, including capabilities and limitations. The physical aspects of radar and underwater sound are described. Facets of command, control, communications, computers, and intelligence are explored as a means of weapons system integration.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 230-0 Leadership and Management Seminar for Naval Officers (1 Unit)
description: The course introduces the student to many of the fundamental concepts of leading Sailors and Marines, which shall be expanded upon during the continuum of leadership development throughout NROTC. It develops the elements of leadership vital to the effectiveness of Navy/Marine Corps officers by reviewing the theories and parameters of leadership and management within and outside of the Naval Service.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 331-0 Naval Operations (1 Unit)
description: This course is a continued study of relative motion, formation tactics, and ship employment. It includes introductions to Naval operations and operations analysis, ship behavior and characteristics in maneuvering, applied aspects of ship handling, afloat communications, Naval command and control, Naval warfare areas, and joint warfare.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 336-0 Evolution of Warfare (1 Unit)
description: Students trace the development of warfare to the present day. It is designed to cover the causes of continuity and change in the means and methods of warfare. It addresses the influence of political, economic, and societal factors on the conduct of war, with significant attention focused on the role of technological innovation in changing the battlefield. Students will explore the contribution of preeminent military theorists and battlefield commanders to our modern understanding of the art and science of war.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 338-0 Fundamentals of Maneuver Warfare (1 Unit)
description: Fundamentals of Maneuver Warfare is a course designed to introduce you to the core principles and history of the United States Marine Corps (USMC) as the premier organization in maneuver warfare. This course blends theoretical knowledge with practical insights, utilizing historical examples from past military operations and current doctrine to develop critical thinkers and scholars in the profession of arms.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 341-0 Naval Leadership and Ethics (1 Unit)
description: The course integrates an intellectual exploration of Western moral traditions and ethical philosophy with a variety of topics, such as military leadership, core values, professional ethics, the Uniform Code of Military Justice, Navy regulations, and discussions relating to the roles of enlisted members, junior and senior officers, command relationships, and the ethical conduct of warfare.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 345-0 Naval Ship Systems I - Naval Engineering (1 Unit)
description: Students learn detailed ship design, hydrodynamic forces, stability, propulsion, electrical theory and distribution, hydraulic theory and ship control, and damage control. The course includes basic concepts of theory/design of steam, gas turbine, diesel, and nuclear propulsion. Case studies on leadership/ethical issues in the engineering arena are also covered.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 350-0 Naval Science Lab (0 Unit)
description: Topics shall cover general Navy/Marine Corps mission and policies, force protection, operational security, watch standing, physical fitness, nutrition, stress management, and other professional development subjects not normally included in the curriculum of the Naval Science courses.

subject: NAV_SCI
title_units: NAV_SCI 355-0 Directed Study (0 Unit)
description: © 2022-2023 Northwestern University Campus Emergency Information Careers Contact Northwestern University Disclaimer Report an Accessibility Issue University Policies Contact Information Office of the Registrar address 633 Clark Street Evanston, IL 60208-1118 Evanston phone number (847) 491-5234 Fax (847) 491-8458 Email Northwestern Registrar's Office nu-registrar@northwestern.edu Social Media Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Additional Links Bookstore Directory Library Maps Media Relations Parking Shuttles Student Complaint Procedure Back to Top Print Options Send Page to Printer Print this page.
